job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Houston, TX
pros: -Benefits (Healthcare - medical covered; 401K match at ~7% I believe) -Ample PTO (but good luck getting it approved)
cons: -Low pay compared to similar positions in the medical center. It is a well-known fact that employees have quit MDACC and go to another hospital system just to then return to MD Anderson after a year or or two to have a fair market salary –– which is ridiculous for retention incentives. -Poor management and HIGH turnover on P7 - despite it being a very high-performing unit institutionally. You would think then that the higher-up department would look into why turnover is so high, but they don't ask and nothing is being done. 1 year new grads are training for charge nurse because staffing is so bad.

review_title: Working at a Leading Cancer Center
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: I have had the privilege of being an employee at MD Anderson, and I can confidently say that it has been an exceptional experience. From the moment I joined the organization, I knew I was part of something truly remarkable. As a renowned cancer center, MD Anderson is synonymous with excellence, innovation, and compassion in the healthcare industry. One of the most remarkable aspects of working at MD Anderson is the culture. It is a place where collaboration and teamwork thrive. From the top down, there is a genuine commitment to patient care and advancing cancer research. The sense of purpose and dedication among the staff is inspiring, creating a positive and supportive work environment.
cons: Competitive Environment: The high level of talent and expertise among employees can create a competitive environment.

review_title: You choose your path. The doors and opportunities old and new are there and willing to share!
pros: There are positions that are easy rides but necessary, and there are positions and projects that may challenge your abilities. That second one is why I’m here. For the challenge. Leadership isnt calling it challenge, aure they encourage and influence in a positive manner, but think of what all it takes to end cancer, to provide the best care for all cancer hospitals, and all operations that support them. The kindness and caring that is spread amongst all is refreshing. Your voice is safe. You security, life, and well being is safe, and you’re safe to discover! Which ever route you choose, you are provided with an abundant amount of tools and resources to use to create and innovate to a degree that makes not only yourself feel good and build strong confidence, but you are literally supporting the overall mission of ending cancer. Supporting your team, your family, your patients, and their families. Everyone at MDACC is built of integrity. Every day is a new rewarding day. Even when they are hard.
cons: It’s a big complex and dynamic place to work, and takes a long time to fully understand all operations md organizational structure and functions, but if you just ask.. they will tell you. If you haven’t worked in fast paced, safe, efficient healthcare org before and your a very detail oriented individual… learn how to read or understand who your audience is… short and seeet sometimes gives exactly the answer an executive needs, but sometimes that executive is not the only person in the room, and your story may need a few more details. You should coontinue on to finish… as you were tasked to do and as you were approved to do even if asked to cut off. In the end your message will be heard much louder and appreciated greater!

review_title: Ask questions, ask questions, ask questions
pros: The best thing is benefits are free to the employee and you only pay for dependents covered on your plan.
cons: I was offered the opportunity a month in advance and communicated with managements quite often and no one ever mentioned how horrible the parking is for MD Anderson. Everything includes a waiting list. The manager's main focus was me being comfortable with the commute but completed omitted the issues with parking so I was forced to park 1 mile away, using my personal privileges and walk 20 minutes to and from my car daily. Sometimes weather was an issue. The manager offered zero assistance with parking and intentionally omitted the MD Anderson parking issues. It felt like a conniving, "dont ask, dont tell" type of situation. Attempting to make sure the employee is able to fully commit to the position is necessary BUT completely omitting issues with parking and ignoring the employees request for parking assistance is a stab at leadership's integrity beyond their MD Anderson position. There were daily hurdles to jump to make it into work and a lot of it was omitted. The director of the department and HR consultants were also no help. Compared to other TMC parking, MD Anderson, by far has the worst parking I have seen in 15 years and with all the funding and assistance they received, you'd assume it was at least comparable to neighboring entities but it is not. Not only this but with one of my paychecks. It was mailed to me and disputed without explanation or notice. More than 1 week later I found out payroll miscalculated my work hours. Anyone applying, ask questions. The manager is horrible and she was able to carry on as such because of her manager's/director and HR's response to her behaviors. I pray all managers are not this way.

review_title: The benefits are great and the environment is very inclusive!
job_title: Research Data Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: There are many pros with working here including all the benefits of PTO, all necessary insurances, paid holidays, and other forms of time off especially for mental health reasons. The managers I work under are very understanding and encouraging of taking time off when it comes to our physical and mental health. Working here is a good place for long-term and building up your retirement fund.
cons: The main "con" about MD Anderson (really applies to all state owned institutions) is that your pay is based off of years of experience in the field and not what you bring to the company. According to my work experience, I "technically" have under 1 year experience in the field because my other experiences were not paid, full-time jobs. Due to that, my salary is dependent on that information and not the skills and value I've brought to the team during my time being here. I personally feel that it's holding back my growth too since my managers aren't able to give me anymore work since that would be considered the next level role in our department. I know this isn't MD Anderson's doing but if you want to work at a place you can grow and get paid your worth, then just don't work at a state-owned institution.

review_title: It used to be a great department. It has really gone downhill with the current department management.
pros: One day of working from home
cons:
It is hard to know where to start. Management talks a good game to your face but at the end of the day, they don't care about your thoughts on how to improve the department. What is wild is that they ask for feedback and then they don't do anything with it! 

People are leaving left and right and we are constantly getting new people. We can't trust what our managers say because we have been lied to several times about really small things. 

There is no effort to address racism or xenophobia in the department and when this is brought up in a meeting, managers are silent. It is obvious that they are uncomfortable addressing these topics but our BIPOC staff are leaving in droves with no change in sight.

Our managers pit us against each other also. They talk about other employees to us and warn us from associating with certain people who are at the bottom of their list. If you speak out and share your opinion, you are automatically blacklisted EVEN THOUGH THEY ASK FOR FEEDBACK.

It is the most gaslighting, toxic workplace that I have ever been part of and that really sucks because it used to be wonderful before the current associate director took over. I have watched the department go downhill ever since and it is sad and disappointing all at once.

job_title: Patient Access Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: We help people get in to MDACC as new patients, insurance and retirement plans are the best.
cons: This review is strictly about the department of Patient Access-not other departments. The COVID-19 pandemic impacted all of MDACC heavily, new patient numbers trying to get in to MDA went down significantly especially during the beginning of the pandemic, however, it also steadily and rather quickly picked back up to pre-pandemic levels. Our main problem was staffing—all centers were told we’re short staffed, however, the director of Patient Access kept trying to push a new agenda in how Patient Access processes new patient referrals. Staff were unequally shifted to other departments only burying those already short staffed to be even further short staffed. Patients were not happy, doctors and clinical teams were not happy—we were not happy. We have tried to ask for overtime for our Patient Access Representatives, and we’re denied multiple times even after direct conversation with the director that she would look into our problems. Every time we brought it up to her it was almost as if it was the first time she has ever heard of it. I used to love this job but the director has shown favoritism, bias (she cherry picks the staff she wants by her side) and intimidation.

review_title: Good Peer Support but Disconnected Management
job_title: Social Work Counselor in Houston, TX
pros:
-Easy to take time off (except for weekend staff)
-Supportive network of colleagues among frontline workers
-Valuable clinical experience 
-Stability of state organization 
-Pension for vested employees
-Onsite LCSW supervision (main campus)
cons:
-Large institution where change is very slow
-Disconnected department management does not align with values and message from executive leadership 
-Failure to provide a safe, supportive space for POC to share their experiences of racism and inequality 
-Explicit gaslighting of social workers’ concerns and feedback, fostering mistrust in the department
-Reduced support for social workers’ self care needs at the expense of rising patient needs
-Blacklisting workers when they speak out with their concerns despite the “open door policy”
-High turnover rate of workforce 

Overall, this does not feel like a psychologically safe place to work within the social work department. The majority of support comes from peers, who are also stretched thin without relief. It is unfortunate that the management, who are also social workers by training, do not show the level of empathy for their staff that they would insist upon when working with patients. The frontline social workers are doing their best given the limitations of support they have been provided, but it often feels like it is never enough as management continues to raise expectations without an end in sight. Morale is low, and you can feel the tension during staff meetings. No one speaks up anymore with concerns, because everyone is tired and beaten down psychologically. We have lost our diversity as many of our diverse staff have gone within the last year. Management is fostering a department of workers who are silently compliant, which is to their advantage when voicing concerns just creates more trouble for everyone. They are holding the line of forever moving forward, never pausing long enough to take stock of the battlefield around them and how many of their comrades have fallen.

pros: It has been about a month since I started working for MD Anderson Cancer Center. I cannot tell you enough just in one single review, this is the best place I had ever worker during my career. When you are looking for an employer, you always want to be with the best one. I did an extent research trying to find out what was great about working with MD Anderson, but you are never going to find out until you actually start working here. First and the most important favor is the cause why we are all here, to help and contribute to eliminate cancer. Every single employee, doesn’t matter what position, department or level is important as anyone else. I had never felt so proud to say where I work and what I do until I started at MD Anderson. I feel very blessed by having the opportunity to work for MD Anderson, this organization not only cares about its patients, but also takes care of its employees. I do not know any other employer that would have what we have in campus.  You just need to work here…
cons: I don’t really have anything negative to say about the institution, other than I wish they would make more affordable parking for employees. The parking can be limited and expensive. It does not affect me since MD Anderson has a program for commuters. I live in EADO so I take the metro rail and MD Anderson, will deduct the amount I select pre-tax to pay for it. review_title: I wish they would have given me an honest chance.
pros:
Probably one of the cleanest hospitals I've ever been to.
Very friendly staff.
So many places to relax and eat.
cons:
I applied for many jobs that I felt I was capable of doing, however, I was ultimately selected to interview for a position that required virtually 0 skills.  I have my bachelors (health related). They offered me $23,000 for this position, and I took it because I was fresh out of college with no hospital experience and could not even secure an interview with any other company. Even still, I tried to negotiate the salary but the recruiter was rude so I stopped.  A year later,  after adding all of my earnings, I see that I only took home a little over $19,000.  I also paid $2,280 in parking garage fees.

I felt sick when I realized this! I didn't acquire any new skills to help my career going forward, and I was severely underpaid. There was so much money being taken out of each check for taxes and benefits, and you can't even adjust it. The patients are lovely and people in other departments are very kind and helpful (at least in my experience). I was really looking forward to staying and growing with this company, but looking back, they obviously did not value me. I would be hesitant about ever returning.

review_title: A business trying to mask itself as an academic institution
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Smithville, TX
pros: The staff in general are pretty helpful, atleast in the satellite campus at science park where I work most of the time. The talent here is great, and so is the student community. If you have a passion for science, this is a good place to be. Seminars are held pretty regularly, and the organisers invite a lot of reknowned folk to give talks. Time off policies are a bit weird ( in the not good sense) when you start off, but I've heard they get better with time. As always, if you're in the good graces of your higher up, you'll have more doors opened for you.
cons: The bureaucracy is stifling, even though the said bureaucrats try and help you out as much as possible. It's pretty evident that MD Anderson was designed/built to run like a business, but is trying to put on a cloak of being an academic institution.  Also their new drug testing policy (effective Jan 1st 2015, MD Anderson is going to become a tobacco free campus) feels like management is going down a slippery slope. Also, new workers have to undergo a LOT of training in paperwork and in general, there are a lot of forms to fill out before doing anything - that too on software systems that were out of date in the early 2000's

review_title: Okay place to gain experience, moving up is difficult.
pros: MD Anderson can be a great place to work. They do have one of the best benefit packages out of my entire work history compared to other healthcare institutions in the medical center, and in the long run those benefits can really be quite the advantage for their employees. They do have positions galore to TRY and move into or possibly be promoted to. Depending what department you work in; your work schedule can be flexible.
cons: Although MD Anderson has many positions to move into, well good luck trying to land one. The positions posted in their internal employee site are either already reserved for someone else in that current department or you have to know someone really well to get into that position. Other than that, you'll spend months applying to positions with no call of an interview. The pay for the positions can also be better. Some of the requirements are quite out of this world for the pay. You have people with BS, Masters, and MD degrees only making mid 50's a year, yet the work load and expectencies can be very much stressful. Directors also need to get a hold of their Managers. Some Managers really don't need to be in that management position but the directors of the department tend to play the blind eye, sort of a out of sight out of mind thing. Directors tend to promise and assure people that things are going to get better and what not, yet months down the line it's the same negative situation reappearing with managers.

review_title: leadership change has damaged culture and integrity of a once great institution
pros: The majority of faculty and staff are very committed to the mission and vision of this once great institution which is to provide the best treatment for cancer patients and to develop much better approaches to treat and hopefully cure cancer patients.
cons: The new leadership is arrogant, nepotistic, ruthless and driven by their own personal agendas. Their behavior has embarrassed the faculty and staff in a very public way. They have set of a two tier system, where the new hires for the "Institute" developed by new leadership are paid 2-3 times what faculty and staff are while not being held to the same performance standards. Faculty morale is at an all time low, with >50% of faculty stating that they will leave within the next 3-5 years. The leadership style has been very destructive and has resulted in faculty fleeing from this once great institution on a weekly basis. There have been multiple demotions and firings of faculty and staff who do not do the bidding of the new leadership. The national press is now calling for a downgrading of the #1 rating of MD Anderson in Cancer Care by the US News and World Report. Although once this happens -and it will happen- the leadership will be called to account for this actions, it will be much too late to recover from the multiple programs that have been destroyed. We have become a laughingstock nationally, with a recognition that the grand "Moonshot Program" is nothing more than a fund raising ploy to provide money to supper the senior leadership research programs in this era of low grant funds and sequestrations.

review_title: Review for M.D. Anderson Cancer Center
pros: It is the number 1 ranked cancer hospital in the United States and it feels great to work for an organization that has such a vital and worthwhile mission.  There is more of a "family atmosphere" as compared to other jobs that I have had in "Corporate America".  Work/life balance is encouraged and respected.  It is a very secure and stable place to work (part of the University of Texas, healthcare, multi-billion dollar annual revenues, receives large private donations).  Employees are automatically enrolled in TRS (teacher's retirement - it's a pension plan).
cons: It is run by doctors from the top down and there is a feeling at times that "the inmates are running the asylum".  Decisions appear to be made by listening to whomever squeaks the loudest as opposed to stepping back and making strategic decisions for the good of the organization as a whole.

pros: Good work environment and culture

job_title: Quality Management Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: The people that work here are incredible. Intelligent, purpose driven, and empathetic. So many people have the patient's best interest at heart and are solution focused. New leadership is making great progress towards greater access and benefits for cancer patients and placing greater value on each member of the team rather than concentrating on members who can directly create revenue. The diversity of the work force is inspirational and contributes towards innovations in care and inclusion. Leadership is communicating decision-making and goals with believable transparency.  New focus on emotional intelligence will help to recruit better middle management.
cons: Process reform is on-going and replacing the uber-political advancement track with merit-based advancement takes time. It is often said that you have to leave and come back for a promotion...low value on retention of skilled, longevity employees. No paid maternity leave or gradual back to work programs. No on-site childcare.

review_title: Great organization, bad (soon to be former) President
pros: They offer fantastic benefits, competitive salary, great PTO that increases with number of years of state service, good work/life balance, good opportunities for advancement, free gym access, including group classes, good management that listens, you are rewarded for good work.
cons: Parking is expensive (it's charged on a tiered level: the larger your salary, the higher your parking costs) & in high demand. If you can take Metro, or don't mind parking in a garage further away & taking the MDA shuttle, it will save you a lot of money. Dr. DiPinho really screwed the institution by being overly cocky & not listening to recommendations & warnings from others which cost MDA over $600M in losses in just a few months, which cost almost 1000 really great people to lose their jobs through no fault of their own. Hopefully they will find a better replacement for him.

pros: State benefits are good, teachers retirement, wonderful patients and the best cancer tx anywhere. Reseach is impressive and groundbreaking.
cons: Low morale and finger pointing has replaced core values caring, integrity in past few years. Very political.  Be careful if you cross the wrong person. People here have long memories and hold bitter grudges.  Some senior managers have a different agenda and it is all about what you do that makes them look good. Credit often goes to those who take credit for it and actually did nothing to deserve it. Blaming is often the name of the game.  It is a shame.

pros: The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center (UTMDACC) may be #1 for cancer care but is also #1 for employee well-being. I attended the Pride Month Celebration event held at UTMDACC for our LGBT employee’s and patients. Even though I myself am not identified as a member of the LGBT community, I actively support these individuals right to equality. I walked in the pride parade last year with the MD Anderson LGBT Employee Network and am looking forward to participating again this year. Having the MD Anderson President, our senior leadership team, and my fellow employees stand side by side to celebrate Pride is one of the many ways in which this organization demonstrates the value of our people. They welcome diversity and work together daily to ensure MD Anderson is place where people can be their true selves. Not many can say that their company practices inclusion at such depth. For this, thank you UTMDACC for making this a great place to work.
cons: I do not have any cons to report at this time.

review_title: Nepotism, Bullying, Sexual Harassment, Religious/Racial Prejudice, Retaliation for Reporting Compliance Violations
pros: Salary and Benefits. Many excellent treatment opportunities for patients.
cons: In the 18 years I worked at MDA before successfully retiring with excellent retirement benefits, I witnessed massive financial waste, nepotism, bullying, sexual harassment, religious and racial prejudice, and retaliation for reporting compliance violations. Additionally, the administration has been historically very poor with HR ignoring many complaints.  Nepotism is rampant and there are the many inappropriate public displays of affection between employees including attending physicians who openly solicit personal relationships with other physicians as well as employees working under them including vulnerable new fellows who rely on these attending physicians for good reviews and future employment. I witnessed many examples of inappropriate public displays of affection as well as bullying and sexual harassment. I also witnessed compliance violations that, when they were reported, resulted in retaliation against the employee reporting the violation.  I watched management in quite a few departments frequently abuse, bully, and harass excellent employees.

review_title: Clinical Research Finance- Do not apply here in any circumstance.
job_title: Clinical Research Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: The only pro is the name of the institute which is in shambles at present so there is no use to look for anything here.
cons:
The worst management ever witnessed/ I have worked with. Upper management has political agendas and emotionally abuse there employees. Starting from the under qualified managers (puppets) who are actually enabled due to favoritism; everything seems to be chaotic. The employees/staff however are usually bearable. 
There is a constant sense of fear in the office with little to none job security. No one has the courage to speak out there minds unless they have a death wish. 
The salary is insufficient and there are no such things as raises/promotions. The management create a fiercely competitive unhealthy environment which inhibits the employees ability for growth and progression. If you require a job where there is no future and no rewards this is the perfect place to exist; old employees that do not adapt to change are very much welcomed here. My employment is only due to need basis and due to shortage of available jobs in the area. If any other jobs that suit my credentials are out there I will at once quit this.

pros: Until I started working at MD Anderson, every company or job was just that . . . a job. Some companies were really good and I enjoyed both the work and the environment but it was never more than a job. Working at MD Anderson is a mission, an opportunity to serve our patients and other employees in everything that I do. If I'm having a bad day or frustrated, I take a walk around the hospital and I'm immediately reminded why I work here. The caring that is displayed daily is inspiring and fulfilling to me. The culture is continuing to transform in more positive and collaborative ways and I want to continue working here to see how far we can go.
cons: Nothing is easy from navigating to communicating to caring for our patients to breakthrough research. Our mission is to end cancer. But, you aren't alone in anything and you will find support from leaders, coworkers and our patients as well. You just need to understand that working here requires you to give your best, think critically and work as a team.

review_title: Good in spots and bad in others

job_title: Research Assistant I in Houston, TX
pros: There is a lot of exciting things going on at MD Anderson.  I liked the fact that I was permitted to go attend one of the many lectures and seminars that are going on a daily basis by the center's experts and guest speakers. I would have loved to keep doing it, but it is hard to make it.  I left the job to go to pharmacy school.
cons: Some of the bosses use you for cheap labor and don't teach you anything along the way.  Try to get into a laboratory where there's a graduate student that is willing to show you some things.  Some of the work can be pretty repetitive.  But if you show initiative, your boss or mentor will probably allow you to run a couple projects of your own.   Also, it takes awhile to advance in the company, and the pay is not always good.  As a research assistant, you could eventually work your way up to lab manager, but now days it seems that they are looking more and more for MBAs and PhDs to run the lab.

pros:
-Great teaching hospital that fosters excellence amongst their employees. The institution helped with my tuition expenses while I was going through graduate school. Leadership and management are very supportive with furthering education. 
-I've worked on this floor for seven years and have floated to different units of the hospital. I can honestly say that this is one of the best units to work on for any nurse. I started here as a graduate nurse and grown in so many ways.
-2-3 patient to nurse ratio. 
-Your working environment really depends on who you work with. MD Anderson follows a team based approach where a group of nurses work together on a nursing "pod." Thus, you are working with the same group of nurses day in and day out. At first, I wasn't a fan of this. But I can tell you that it fostered a great relationship amongst my co-workers and definitely makes my day better.
cons: -Sometimes, the unit is short staffed-only 4 nurses to a "pod" and sometimes without a nursing assistant. Whenever there are 4 nurses to a pod, all nurses have 3 patients-regardless of their acuity.

pros: I really enjoyed the staff in all other departments. Stay clear of the pulmonary clinic on the 6th floor.
cons:
Workplace clique that entertain themselves daily by excluding, making fun of, gossiping, spreading false rumors, and bullying their newest target. The few that may not agree with what is going on contribute with their silence. Management is part of said group so there is no recourse. If you fit into this type of clique, this may be the job for you. If not, it is a very painful, daily experience.
The clinic nurse position is very unsatisfying for a nurse that takes pride in her skills and wants to work at the top of her license. It really is a role for an MA. I actually was hired to do the same job an MA had been doing for years, and was trained by an MA. A waste of resources for so many other departments lacking in help and funds. The miscommunication between departments causes many issues for cancer patients whom are already overwhelmed. And finally, the Physician was just out of school, young and arrogant. He was more concerned about his appearance than his patients. How he talked and joked about his patients was disgusting. MD Anderson is a great hospital in Houston...not Jax.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros:
Access to collaboration with world-leaders in oncology and cancer research.
Access to a large and wonderful library through which any article or book can be found.
cons:
Parking is terrible and very expensive!
Living in an apartment in the near vicinity is extremely expensive. Most people, therefore, have to live afar and commute. The traffic is a kiler!
There is a lack of organization and taking care of employees' vital needs while there is a barrage of unclear requests and demands on employees to complete.
Health insurance is very expensive and mandatory, which seems to me, unconstitutional!
Pay is very low.
Some of the faculty is very old and they refuse to retire, blocking the advancement of other younger faculty.
The goals and targets for research or projects are very unclear. There is no intercommunication between top management and researchers. Research assistants are usually kept out of the loop until the last minute and a barrage of issues are given them for implementation at the last minute, which threatens and hinders completion of projects on time.

review_title: Not really what you know, but "Who" you know and "Who" has "POWER"
pros: competitive salary, most folks are friendly and willing to share knowledge, mentoring environment, many educational and training courses are offered for advancement within the institution.
cons: It's not what you know, but who you know environment. Fear of retalitaion from upper management is frequently a concern across the institution. Many in management positions are office bullies, and often threaten employees to ensure processes are carried out their way. Even though the way they want it carried out may not be the very best or logical way...they want it their way.  Additionally, I have experienced going above and beyond my call of duty for years, only to receive pennies as monetary compensation.  Needless to say, I've often witnessed a severe lack of caring, integrity, and character in upper management. Additionally, on a few occasions, as sad as it is, I've even seen forms of racisim. It's right under the radar, but it's here. In some shape, form or fashion, employees have to pay to come to work. Either paying to ride a bus, van pool, or ridiculous parking prices for a local garage.

review_title: Great in inpatient.  Bad in outpatient.
job_title: Patient Services Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: Continously learning. Diversity. Have all the tools needed. Benefits are great.
cons: Experienced from Mays Clinic at a particular department. If you are not friends with your boss or colleagues (outside work), not the favorite, or just being dislike because of your "beliefs", no matter how hard you put your heart into helping patients, the management will find ways to make your life miserable by being called about mistakes while others (they like) gets away. No voice to say anything because Directors/Management's are close FRIENDS with HR. They don't promote growth in education especially if you wanted to transfer because HR will inform your department. Then they will put you on notice for one year. They have high turn over rate in that particular department. They will put lies in your evaluation goals. They would hire someone outside from a restaurant with no experience for the same position you have and pay her double amount of your salary maybe because she is a friend or a family member (you do not matter). If you give your 2 weeks notice, expect that you will be terminated.

job_title: Senior Research Scientist in Houston, TX
pros:
The anchor of the Texas Medical Center (TMC). MDACC has 21,000 employees, 2,000 of whom are faculty (clinical and/or research). TMC has ~100,000 employees, same amount of office space as downtown Houston, and the world's largest parking concession.
Cancer patients can get about equally great treatment at MDACC as any of the other top ten NCI designated cancer centers in the US - go to one of these, not Joe's for profit cancer center that happens to be in your town.
Texas does not have a state income tax. Air conditioning bill in Houston can be less than heating & A/C in the north.
cons:
Lots of silos, not much communication between them. Competition can be as fierce within MDACC as it is between MDACC and other leading cancer centers.

Don't drive on I-10 through downtown during heavy rains. Don't live in or near a low spot - prone to flooding.

Culture & values: "We do things the Anderson way" = the same way for the past 20 years. If your prospective manager uses this phrase during your interview, don't take the job.

pros: M. D. Anderson has excellent benefits.  Furthermore, working with the departments and physicians is interesting and a wonderful opportunity for learning.  M.D. Anderson does promote telecommuting from the Business Office.
cons: M.D. Anderson has some of the worst managers I've ever worked with.  Anyone who files a complaint or grievance is retaliated against and driven to resign.  The managers with whom I worked did not know the jobs of those they managed and therefore created unrealistic production expectations.  The pressure was to get the charges in even if they were incorrect.  It is the most stressful place I have ever worked.It was not uncommon for the exempt employees to work 60 hours a week. There is a horrible work/life balance even though Anderson says it promotes work/life balance.  The physicians and mid-level providers are wonderful to work with.

review_title: Do not let the reputation FOOL you!
pros:
Benefits  are excellent.
iDeal discounts. We get discounts on a lot of services from Cell Phones Providers to Houston Zoo Admission price
Patients are usually treated with the best level of care.
cons:
Politics! Politics! Politics! 
Management very cold hearted and have no compassion for employees.
Parking is way too expensive. 
Low morale
Brown nosers' haven - your skills and work ethic doesn't matter here. 
Some managers are OVER PAID and are completely clueless about the roles of the employees they "micro-manage"
High turn over rate in some departments due to poor management and operational flaws.
HR does very little to help employees against abuse, harrassment and bulllyinf from bosses.

review_title: Great Place to Work and Retire From
pros: I have worked for M.D. Anderson for the past twenty years.  I have never seen or heard of a better hospital to work in.  From upper-management, to faculty, to supervisors, to staff, MDA has aimed to create employee retention and employee satisfaction.  MDA continue to be the favorite of the hospitals in the Houston area.  Just understanding how your job affects the people around you and the patients, made me proud to be a part of the family.
cons: If you do not know someone within the company, it will be hard to become a employee within M.D. unless you are highly qualified for a lower position.  The good buddy system is a plus to some, but can hurt others.  The hiring process lacks its ability to hire out-of-network applicants.  Upper management has also grown substantially. Too many chiefs in some divisions.

review_title: Core Values taking a back seat to money and egos?
pros: Mission to cure cancer is worthwhile.  Providing life-giving treatment to cancer patients is it's own reward.  Some of the most brilliant and dedicated oncologists and healthcare professionals in the world work here.  Very good employee benefits and excellent retirement plan if you can stay for the long haul.
cons: The big business of caring has taken a back seat to egos and money.  Lack of trust in upper management is at an all time high and getting worse.  Fear of retaliation is a problem for a reason.  Upper managers seem to think themselves untouchable. Some areas are chronically short staffed and staff have to work in ridiculously tight spaces.

job_title: Senior Clinical Research Specialist in Houston, TX
pros: Amazing learning experiences in the world of cancer research and treatment. As a nurse there are a lot of different opportunities to grow. Pay and benefits are good, depending on your department.  You can accrue a large amount of vacation time the longer you are employed.  There is a lot of effort to provide a good work/life balance.  There is currently a large full-service exercise/work out area in one of the buildings.
cons: Everything depends on how your department is managed.  Some people have lost their jobs due ot poor management and budget cuts.  The environment is very political as is most academic institutions.  As mentioned above, the benefits are good, but most have difficutly taking their vacation time.  I am leaving my position because of micromanagement and the difficulty getting time off approved.  This is because of my department director's managment style.  There is no other position in MD Anderson with my title and pay scale.

pros:
As a long-term employee I have been here for some ups and downs.  With our new leadership, I feel we are really on our way to a more successful business with happier employees.  The focus on servant leadership and a better feedback loop has been very successful. 

Pros: Positive leadership, diverse community, great benefits, educational opportunities, community feeling, shared goals, feelings of making a true difference
cons:
The main cons of MD Anderson seem to be resolving for the most part with new leadership.  A major cons  is the cost of parking and difficult and unreliable transportation system.  

There is still some work that needs to be done on work/life balance.  I have major concerns about required 7 am meetings, for example.  Since many daycare centers do not open until 6:30, I find this requirement especially burdensome on parents.  When I was a single mother I was unable to attend these meetings and I think it had an impact on career growth.

review_title: Very Poor Leadership and Direction with horrible planning for the future.
pros: The employees are great people.  Well most of them anyway.  The services that they provide are great for people in need of their services.
cons: The management of the IT&S division is horrible.  There is no planning of any type of project.  Everything is done by the seat of their pants.  Absolutely no accountability for upper management when HUGE mistakes are made that effect patient care at all.  Usually they end up getting promoted to another position or sent to somewhere that is a lateral move  to take the pressure off answering the questions that people are asking.  They are forcing people into working 12hr  24x7  schedules that keep them away from their families because management sat on their hands for two years on a project and now the go live date is near and they are scrambling.  We are now on the fourth management group for IT&S.

job_title: Senior Research Data Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros:
Teamwork is definitely a pro around my department. Despite we all have specific assignments, there is always a helping hand available. Whenever I need assistance with my assignments, colleagues are always quick to assist in order to move forward. My immediate leadership also constantly reviews workloads and spreads them out among the team in order to avoid becoming burned out. 
Growth is another huge pro throughout all of MD Anderson. Everyone is encouraged to continue attaining training and higher education through programs, information sessions, and financial assistance. All are also encouraged to go up in the employment ladder and in most cases it happens in such a short time.
Finally benefits are a bonus for all full-time employees.
cons: A con is the fact that the pay could be better for the amount of workload that we have. Higher salaries should be offered to internal employees rather than external employees. Another con is the lack of uniformity in training throughout various departments. For example, in my department, there are 8+ teams. Although we all perform the same duties, the training varies.

review_title: A good employer with excellent benefits, leading edge research facilities and boundless opportunities
pros: A world class cancer research facility with leading edge technologies. Great people, and very good work /life balance. Middle management does try to meet the expectations of the extremely diverse workforce.
cons: Excessive political correctness, one must be very careful during casual conversations not to say anything that might be taken in the wrong context. In some cases, departmental meetings are not well structured, no process check, items brought up not on agenda.and outside the scope of the meeting. When assigned to work on special projects, very seldom were clear objectives set with defined dates for specific milestones. Projects tended to be open ended.

pros:
M. D. Anderson offers amazing health benefits. They pay for the employee's health insurance and then the employee can add spouse & children for a reasonable amount. Eye & dental is super inexpensive. Just overall great benefits. 
The animals are so great to work with. It's such an incredible experience.
cons:
A good portion of the employees at the Keeling Center Campus in Bastrop don't make enough to cover cost of living in the area. 
Higher management does not hold lower management accountable for helping in their areas when they need to. When complaints are made, higher management tends to turn a blind eye instead of confronting the problem. Or they just give a slap on the wrist to the supervisors to try and appease the people who have made complaints.

review_title: Disappointed in our mission taking a back seat
pros: Opportunity to work with the best minds in finding  a cure for cancer.  Many dedicated employees who still concentrate on quality patient care are keeping the place afloat.  Patients are wonderful, hopeful, giving and worthwhile.
cons: Too many chiefs who are more into $, power and prestige than patients or a cure for cancer -unless it can make them more money.  Conflict of Interest questions are embarassing to those of us who just want to concentrate on what we are supposed to be all about.  Seems to just keep moving further downhill in the CARING and INTEGRITY department.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Houston, TX
pros: Patients. Learning about cancer and all the new things they are doing to cure it
cons: Layoffs. Clock- in down to the exact minute required and watched now that we are in crisis. We get in trouble if we clock- in online 1 minute early and you can get fired. It doesn't matter if your parking garage is a ten minute walk then you walk in the building is 5 minutes. Even if your peers park in a garage 1 minute away, they still dont care you are spending more time at work. The benefits aren't that good and we have to pay 7% of our paycheck towards retirement fund that we don't even get unless we work here 5 years.

review_title: They will treat people however they want to in a certain area if they do not want you in their dept
pros: You will get to see the same patient information more than once because it is never corrected and the patient just keeps calling and the manager ... that’s a different pro/con
cons: There is not a single soul on that campus that will help you if certain people from certain depts do not like you, want anyone to know that you have knowledge of the job at hand, they will lie for each other and still sleep at night. And say they are Christian. Then the higher ups wont even acknowledge the way they treat people. They praise the ones that don’t know how and write up the ones that know how.

pros: The mission of eliminating cancer makes one feel special and the majority of the employees are committed and know the mission. Great retirement plan.
cons: Extremely political with doctors in charge with egos the size of Texas. The doctors are terrific physicians and scientists but that does not translate to knowing everything about everything. All the doctors have to do is whine to a higher up and they get there way. Bullying is rampant at the highest levels of the organization and no one does anything about it. Money is wasted through duplicate services and allowing the doctors to all have their own unique and customized way of working. The president and his wife plus the cohort of cronies they brought from Boston. The core values of caring, discovery, and integrity are just words and not practiced from the top down. The organization has degraded significantly over the last 10 years and has reached a crisis point.

review_title: The best benefits around, but it's not worth it
pros: The benefits are among the best I've seen. Healthcare is paid by the institution, there is ample vacation time given. Most employees are hard working and personable. Between all the negatives (below) you really do feel like you're making a difference.
cons:
Depending on the department, management can be from at best inept to at worst negligent and dangerous. Problems are ignored until the day before governing bodies do inspection, are hastily patched over, and then forgotten about until the next inspection looms. They have managed to make institutional policies both so weak as to allow lazy, unqualified employees a steady paycheck and so restrictive as to force managers to fire well liked, hardworking employees that have been unlucky. . The institution is facing a possible academic censure from the American Association of University Professors. Morale is at an all time low. 

Run from this place.

review_title: Good company to grow but depends on your managers
job_title: Medical Technician II in Houston, TX
pros: Some of the most brilliant, positive people work here. Overall moral is everyone plays an important role in creating healthier lives. Bonus potential and occasional free swag. Tuition reimbursement. Assistance for almost anything you can think of so long as it's approved by your dept. Shuttle buses are convenient!
cons: Having to pay for parking as the garages are owned by the city and shuttling in. Easily tacks on another 15-20 mins to your work day if you have to use it and depending on which garage you're zoned to. The institution is massive and can sometimes be difficult to get the help you need. My manager was stretched VERY thin as my dept had a fairly high turn over rate. In my 2 years there, I witnessed a handful of employees resign both high and low positions.

pros: Every day a person who works at MD Anderson Cancer Center wakes up knowing they are going to work for a mission that matters. It is not about profit. It is all about curing cancer. Working in IT, I am not involved in direct patient care yet the leaders are careful to be sure we all have line of sight on how we contribute to the mission.
cons: The last two years have been a challenge with all the leadership changes and lack of staffing. Many of us are doing two and three jobs. The stress level is high and uncertainty is making it worse. We hear that this is the "new normal" but we cannot keep up the pace. Many are getting sick and quitting.

review_title: Overall Good company to work for
pros: Retirement package, TRS much better than 401K, keeps your money growing and not really affected by a stock market. The company matches your contribution, vested after 5yrs of service. Medical benefit if free if you're single, means don't include your family, but it still has a co-pay.
cons:
Some of the managers (not all of them) are lazy and greedy, they are not working but enjoy the higher salary. They look nice, but when someone complaint to make improvements for the patients and the workers, they said they will but they don't do it at all.
The HR people are very unorganized, lack of communications. When the nurses and other allied healths served the patient well as a customer, then they must serve us well too as their customers.

job_title: Clinical Research Nurse in Houston, TX
pros: MDA encourages educational growth for all of their employees. We get gracious benefits and access to a nice recreational center for free. There are always events put on by my department to facilitate team building and open-communication. I can talk openly with all of my supervisors about my concerns and they are attentive and understanding.  I have met President Pisters on multiple occasions and he is so down to earth, and always trying to make positive changes. MDA also has organizations for lgbtq, women, and diversity. We recently had an awesome celebration for pride month and they will be a sponsor for the Houston pride parade this year. This is a very wonderful place to work.
cons: Sometimes it's hard to work with this patient population because you want to help everyone, but the nursing training I was provided really helped me deal with this.

review_title: Grand environment but enthusiasm is stifled by control-freaks
pros: MD Anderson Cancer Center is a grand place to work, lots of professionals just a phone call away, which makes collaboration easy. The benefits are great, the support from within the institution is great - from vaccination clinics to legal advice you can get support for nearly anything from MD Anderson.
cons: The management is too controlling and the environment where I worked at was only interested in publications, not actual progress. Concerns about study design were not taken serious. Also request for cell/tissue services costing as little as 3$ had to be countersigned by 2 officials to be placed. More bureaucracy than need be.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: MD Anderson is a beautiful network of research scientists and clinicians all joined to make Cancer history. Aside from a recent noble prize winner, Anderson distinguishes itself from all others by having been the number 1 rated Cancer treatment facility for over 20 years. Due to the distinction, this is an institution that will challenge and make you grow to fulfill that objective. Great place to work and amazing team to work with.
cons: It is a premier institution and will test one's resolve to fulfill that goal. In no way does one here skate through and escape the rigorous work that is a daily grind from the very top of the hospital to the bottom; everyone is challenged always to do one's upmost.

review_title: Unethical Coding caused No. 1 US Ranking for 7 years will not disclose to public
pros: Benefits, flextime, possible telecommuting, I stayed way past the time I should have left ... Due to the great benefits .. In the end I know I should have left for my own sanity
cons: I was actually asked to commit fraud by my manager to bill Medicare patients without the ability to look up documentation for medical necessity. in fact, i was written up for looking at documentation because it cut into the production time and numbers. I went to HR, called the hotline .. Which goes right back to the institution and compliance did nothing about it ...

review_title: Forgotten mission and core values.  Arrogance is a problem.
pros: Decent benefits, work with lots of smart, dedicated people. It is very rewarding to help so many patients in need. TRS retirement is great benefit, if you can sick it out.
cons: MDAnderson, you aren't the only place in town.  Get real.  High level managers in it for themselves have discarded the core value: INTEGRITY.  You still have many hardworking, dedicated employees to keep the place running, But even patients are noticing how you have slipped.  Now it's just business.  That is very sad.  I am not interested in returning.

pros: Benefits, PTO, the diverse environment, employee appreciation month, and I absolutely love the faculty members I work for
cons: Parking prices are ridiculous but that’s the medical center, within MD Anderson its hard to move to other departments, if you don’t know someone who knows someone. The internal positions are posted for a formality because the department already has someone they want in the position. It is a good and bad thing because if your department has the room for growth it’s awesone, but if it doesn’t you are stuck and having to look outside of MDA.  I didn’t get my Master’s degree to continuously get passed up on jobs that I’m qualified for and then find out they hired an individual within the department.

review_title: A great institution to be part of it; I worked here as Senior Statistical Analyst
job_title: Senior Statistical Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: It offers an academic environment with huge community of researchers and investigators. Got opportunity to mange and analyze data with millions of records of cancer patients which would not be available elsewhere.  Inferential statistics which yield new methodologies and new solutions. I developed a new method for early detection of acute kidney injury among cancer patient with creatinine as bio-marker.
cons: Based on the huge size and diverse nature of various departments, HR department works like postoffice and local managers tend to hire like minded people.

pros: Great benefits,  flexible scheduling, opportunity for growth and if needed to change careers to different department.  Making a difference in  our research animals which in turn helps future studies for humans for a better cancer treatment.
cons: Parking, weekend shifts even after working 5 days of the weeks( which leads to working 12 days straight) My department needs improvement in upper management. ( Technicians are more used as glorified mouse cage cleaners than instead working more closely with the researchers) If we hire employees with college degrees we need to use their insight and give them opportunity to use  their educational skills and develop them.

job_title: Community Relations Director in Houston, TX
pros: Love the leadership team...they are true servant leaders with our patients and employees always at the top of their minds. The way that Dr. Pisters has selected his leadership team shows me that he truly cares about who he surrounds himself with and understands that a good leadership team makes a world of difference.  I have worked at MD Anderson for more than 27 years and never have I been more proud of the leaders.  They are doing an awesome job especially in the time of coronavirus.  I have friends and family who now want to work at MD Anderson because they see how the institution is being led during such a  crisis.
cons: Sometimes, business processes like Legal review are slow because they are backed up and don't have enough staff.

review_title: Almost at the 10 year mark and still love coming to work everyday
pros: It's very clean and a nice modern and social environment. Each person who works here feels like we make a difference, it's not just a job. Educational opportunities are pretty good. Nice gym on site and plenty of programs for work/life balance. Very good benefits and retirement package.
cons: There is a lot of red tape here, but I think it would be that way at any place the size of MD Anderson. It's difficult to get promoted or get a decent raise here. The pay is not on par with other positions in different institutions unfortunately. And the workload to staff ratio is very is very uneven a lot of the time.

pros: I love working at MD Anderson! Everyone is committed to working together in making cancer history. Our patients come first! The staff and faculty are great to work with, very respectable and willing to hel you grow! The institution as a whole invests in your future and wants you to continue your education, whether it be completing and achieving your degree all the way up to receiving your PH.D. The benefits are a bonus too!
cons: The only thing I can say that is a con is that the pay can be a little better. Instead of offering higher salaries to those applying from the outside the pay should be higher for internal employees.

review_title: It feels great to be able to help so many people
job_title: Doctor of Pharmacy in Houston, TX
pros: It is very rewarding to be part of the MD Anderson healthcare team; where we are working to cure cancer and truly help so many people. The ability to help others has drawn many like minded staff members and volunteers and has created a supportive and caring culture.   Employees, management and the clinical staff work well together and treat each other respectfully. Professional expertise is appreciated and we have autonomy to make clinical decisions. If you are motivated to make a difference you will have the ability to do it at MD Anderson Cancer Center.
cons: Working in a 24/7 investigational hospital requires good communication between shifts and access to a large amount of people, sometimes it is difficult to find the right person to answer your question.

review_title: World Class Health Care with Lots of Internal Problems
pros:
You can make a positive impact in someone's life every day
Competitive salaries
Great benefits
Nice office space and other amenities, ergonomic help for long hours at the desk
They've successfully eliminated a lot of the counterproductive bureaucracy
cons:
Way too much nepotism and favoritism
Way too much workplace conflict when they claim to all be working toward the same mission with the same values
"Courtesy" job postings/interviews when managers have already identified who they will be hiring, wasting everyone's time
Every department is different and where you go/grow definitely depends on who you work for.  One usually has to leave to achieve any growth and professional development opportunities
Underqualified middle management

review_title: Love it, but looking to leave...
pros: MDA has excellent salary and benefits;  I do believe there is opportunity to grow and it's so large that you can move to different a different department and have a whole new job and experience.  People are great, patient care is beyond reproach.
cons: ALOT of red tape, ALOT of policies and procedures that totally frustrate the faculty and make the job of dept. manager very difficult.  New president and EVP-PIC spend more time on developing "moon shots" and "strategic planning" than actually getting to know the areas and figuring out the real problems.  Morale is low and I would jump ship in a second if given the opportunity.  Many world-class faculty have left and many top executives.  Makes me fearful for what's coming up.

pros: They put the salary on their website, which is rare.  Most companies don't do that.  Also, the health benefits are pretty good, and it's pretty good job security.
cons: Horrible work/life balance.  Very hard to schedule off and LOTS of rules and red tape with employees.  They treat you like a number and there's a lot of gossip, politics, and they will overwork you.  All in all, there are a lot of other hospitals I would recommend to work for that treat their employees way better.

review_title: Good pay, nice people, lots of work.
job_title: Inpatient Services Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: MD Anderson is really a great place to work. Especially if you are looking for the chance to help others. It is a great environment to meet a lot of new people. The patients are usually very appreciative of your help, and there are a lot of wonderful people and stories.
cons: As great as the people were the hours sucked. Working on holidays and weekends is not that cool (even though they pay shift differential). It is not easy to move around MD Anderson. They require you to stay at least 6 months in any position and also require that your boss approves any transfers. If you are a good employee, your department won't want to let you go.

review_title: Great place to work, but BIG and bureaucratic
pros:
Competitive-to-great pay; excellent benefits; on-site gyms, coffee shops, restaurants; beautiful facilities. I have the best coworkers I've ever had. Smart, driven, funny, and hard working. Interesting problems to solve and cool people to solve them with. 

The feeling of mission -destroying  cancer- is very real and something that brings a lot of highly motivated people to work here.
cons:
Your experience will vary a lot depending on which group you land in. Some are tremendously "vertical" and dictatorial, some are much more relaxed. There is also a lot of bureaucracy, as in many 20,000+ person organizations.

Work/life balance will also depend heavily on your department. 

I've had a great career so far, but advancement/promotion opportunities are scarce.

pros: Great company to work for with values based mission and vision. Diverse work force.  Reputable company due to the dedication of hardworking and talented individuals. Perks include tuition reimbursement, use of the gym, discount shopping, and financial rewards for longevity.
cons: Merit based raises are dependent on the discretion of the department administration. The company is large and different departments have different interpretations of policy and procedures. The company could improve in department to department communication and consistency, and flexibility with work schedules. Middle management in research departments are made up of individuals who are not formally trained in management. Salary base is below average with limited room for upward growth without a masters degree or higher.

pros: Great benefits, very good work environment and ability to help others in difficult moments. Training is good and help you to learn everything you need to do even if you know nothing about it.
cons:
You have to pay for parking and it's generally expensive based on the building you are working at.
Management is not fair at all and have favorites. They don't follow their core values when it comes to employees.
It doesn't really matter if you have experience or not. They will hire whomever they want even if the new hire or hires have zero knowledge/experience in any given position.
Career opportunities are based on who you know.

review_title: Amazing from the outside, insane from the inside.
job_title: Research Assistant I in Houston, TX
pros:
Doctors are all top notch, top of their field professionals.
Benefits are great.
Interaction with cancer patients (if in job description) can be a life changer.
cons:
With such top notch doctors, comes almost impossible demands.
Excellent leadership in clinics and as managers is absolutely critical.  In areas where there is subpar management, everyone really suffers.
Not as quick promotion potential - everything takes a serious amount of time.

pros: Great benefits, great people in certain departments, institution makes an effort to improve the employee's well-being
cons:
Too much bureacracy and wasted resources; lack of oversight of operations contributing to wasted resources (mostly financial):
So much potential for improvement, but management doe not have an active role over process improvement; issues are brought up in meetings, but things fall through the cracks, and recommendations are not implemented

pros: The organization's mission and core values, the breadth of service lines available which allows employees to seek diverse areas for professional growth, oncology expertise, employee benefits
cons: Lack of upward mobility, top-heavy leadership structure, culture of "who you know",  lack of equity in staffing allotment

pros: We have an incredible effective leader who sets a wonderful tone of caring for the entire institution from the care of the patients and employees to his enduring strive for transparency and clarity.  A great leader really affects the institution's environment greatly.  MD Anderson is a wonderful place to work for because of our wonderful leader, Dr. Pisters.
cons: It's a pretty large institution and sometimes it takes time to get things done but our current leaders are working really hard to reach all employees. It is a con but our current leaders are doing a great job.

review_title: do not even think about it if you want work/life balance
pros: Good benefits... that about it....
cons: Do not plan to join if you have any self respect and think you can have a normal life. You are expected to work overtime if you are not hourly employee and do not receive any additional pay. If you disagree with your boss, there are some very strange , very old internal policies based on some old MDA culture and traditions that will lead to your resignation (no unemployment) . Just like in an old conspiracy movies you will find yourself in a surreal situation where everyone is against you and HR, your boss and administration is doing everything to push you out! Never speak out against your boss, just quit if you do not like it. They employ pure illegal practices!

review_title: If your're not a nurse or doctor don't waste your time!!
job_title: Patient Services Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: Great pride working for one of the top cancer hospitals in the world.
cons: Very hard to transfer to different departments,  They say you can transfer after 6 months of employment but unless you know someone in management you can't move anywhere,  If you are not a nurse or doctor you will get NO respect,  They tend to look down on nursing assistants, clerks, secretaries etc...  You might as well be invisible.

pros: The benefits are wonderful, office culture is overall culturally diverse which I enjoy because you learn so much from your employees. I like how big this place is because you run into the most wonderful co-workers and patients going through this hospital everyday.
cons: Compensation is ok, but the 2% raise every year you hardly even see it, and the amount it cost to park each month in the parking garages are ridiculous. The slow ability to move up within a company this size is ridiculous, if you are looking to take a position to get your foot in the door I highly recommend you wait for the position you are wanting to move into because it is difficult to move around in this company.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Houston, TX
pros: Working at MD Anderson is the best career move I ever made.  I love working at a company that strives for diversity and acceptance.  My coworkers come from many different backgrounds.  I am an open person at work and never hear negative comments about who I am.  The feeling of inclusion at work for the LGBT community is fantastic.  MD Anderson is a Sponsor of the Pride festival in Houston,  had a Pride Month kick off celebration at the Hospital, and participates in the Pride Parade.  The feeling of inclusion comes from the very TOP where our President made comments at the pride celebration.  MD Anderson is the best example of DIVERSITY and ACCEPTANCE.
cons: Happy to say I Can't think of why not to work here.

review_title: Proud to work at MD Anderson for 10+ years
job_title: Clinical Research Nurse in Houston, TX
pros: I have worked at MD Anderson for 11 years and I am proud to work for such an amazing institution. Our President, Dr. Pisters, genuinely cares about our employees. The health of our workforce is a top priority for him and he ensures that we have the tools necessary for maintaining a healthy work/life balance. The safety of our patients and our workforce members is his highest priority.  He is committed to maintaining transparency and building trust and confidence within our MD Anderson community. Over 21,000 employees work here; we are all family and we look out for each other.
cons: I have experienced no downside to working at MD Anderson.

review_title: It really is a great institution, but...
pros: Salary, promotional opportunities, benefits package and the tons of wonderful patients you meet daily.
cons: There are not enough folks in management who are willing ti stick their necks out for what they know, and behind closed doors will admit, is right.  Everything is so PC.  Not enough middle management, the real work horses, are willing say anything is wrong or unjust for fear of being  alienating by the next level of management.  Everyone wants a title with "Management" attached, but no one really wants to manage.  Sad, because mismanagement is allowed to fester everyday.

job_title: Applications Systems Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: It's a great place to work, especially the position I held as an Analyst. I had the freedom to pretty much schedule my day and perform my daily task with little to no supervision. There are opportunities for career and education advancement you just have to seek them out. Overall I was pleased with the work environment and would recommend them.
cons: The biggest problem I experienced was the disconnect between management and the employees. Too often favoritism played a role in decisions which tended to create a combative environment.  Outside of that I approached anything else as a challenge to be overcame

job_title: Manager, Volunteer & Patient Programs in Houston, TX
pros: The institution's mission, vision and core values are the thrust of what makes MD Anderson Cancer Center the best workplace.  It's because of the established culture and clarity of the strategic plan for accomplishing our goal--to end cancer, that has employees aligned and unified to work together, internally and externally, focused and committed as one.
cons: I'm not sure at this time.  I enjoy working at MD Anderson and perhaps I only see things from the glass half full perspective when it comes to what doesn't work, which can be a con as well as a pro.

review_title: Was great until the new CEO came along...
pros: Location to light rail, career movement/opportunity, benefits, retirement fund (Texas Teachers Retirement Fund)
cons: Variety of benefit options (only one), not allowed to tele-commute (although they complain about the cost of being in the medical center), being essential personnel during storms when not essential personnel, focus on research and not patient care, bonus opportunity non-existent, you get held to a job and not allowed to transfer if they feel they cannot replace you.

pros: Excellent benefits, including health insurance, retirement, TRS annuity, quality, safe health care delivered, impressive company brand, great brand recognition, good resume builder, strong research, great gym, facilities, opportunities
cons: Inefficient, archaic work flows, poor work-life balance, too much administrative burden with decisions being made that make no sense at times, too much top down management at times, slow growth opportunities, lower than average salaries, burnout is high

pros: great place to start your career (and continue!). great wellness center..its free. everyone seems to be nice so far and there is a lot of work to jump in on. you will not be bored if you work here.
cons: Parking is expensive like all TMC organizations. Compensation could be updated to reflect cost of living increase in Houston.

job_title: Facilities Project Manager in Houston, TX
pros: Easier to get foot in the door in a management position than other places.  I now have two years of management experience at a very recognizable institution, looks good on resume.
cons: Pay less than industry average.  Upper management is a bit of a mess.  The whole institution is in a bad financial situation which has raised doubts about the future of the department.

pros: Diversity is an important aspect of MDAnderson,  Dr.Pister showed up for Pride Event Kickoff.
cons: They need to work on work life balances for everyone, not just people in leadership role.  they are very good about talking about work life balances but no actions on their part.

review_title: Great place to work for some department
pros: Good benefits, very diversified, provides good training, good working environment and aims for patient satisfaction.
cons: Too much politics and one department I have worked for has a high turnover of manpower due to its Administrator. Even then, HR are being biased and up to this date according to my former coworkers is not really investigating nor doing any actions about it. There are positions being offered for advancement but normally taken by management's favorite.

review_title: Great place to work - But only for internal referrals - Outsiders don't even bother to apply for a job
pros:
Good reputation as being ranked number one in USA 
Lots of specialties
Good hospital for cancer treatment
New technologies
Sponsor H1B visas
cons: Very poor management. Predominantly hispanic community. They spend a lot of money on buildings and useless meetings and conferences but don't even pay a little for coffee. Clinical side gets all the attention, research people are being exploited. Very low payscale for PhD candidates and post doctoral fellows. On-campus housing is shared with UT-Houston and there is a very long waiting list. Employees need to pay for parking.

pros: Working with the best of the best in oncology research; approachable faculty; co-workers from every area of the world; competitive salaries, beautiful surroundings (buildings/furniture), top-notch equipment.
cons: Recent change in leadership (president) who is reworking how things have been done.  Wants to commercialize.  Lots of changes from the top-down.  Not everyone is happy with the changes.  Also brought some bad press which dedicated employees are having a hard time getting over.  Also since a state agency it is difficult to fire low-achievers and high achievers are overburdened.

review_title: Can't imagine a better place to work as a nurse
pros: Great nursing culture, large hospital with many resources, plenty of room for growth within the organization. Best pay and benefits for nurses.  Teacher's retirement pension plan can't be beat.  Money for you to go back to school $5200/yr on top of your salary.
cons: Division of nursing has been implementing some strict nursing policies on dress code and time and attendance.  There is a point system for being late, forgetting to clock in, calling in sick, etc.  If you accrue too many points it can affect your ability to receive salary increases and job transfers.  DePinho has given MDA a very bad image.  Tired of the negative press that he has brought.

pros: Opportunity to collaborate and meet diversified and talented people from all over the world. Good company benefits, and campus fitness center.  Great social scene in Pickens Tower, Main Hospital, and Duncan building, very isolated in others.  Training and online education is available.
cons: Management of departments is full of young inexperienced managers straight out of MBA school who have no concept of the operations of a large hospital or clinic. Blind trying to lead the blind.  Experienced employees are devalued and underutilized in favor of lower salaries and inexperienced beginners.  Top management are disconnected and have no idea what teams under them are doing.  Too many meetings and too many departments that do the same thing. Left does not know what right does.  Cronyism, backstabbing, favoritism, blackballing.  Your opinion is asked for, but met surprisingly by a silent stone wall.  Choose and move carefully or goodbye career progression.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: I love the employees that I work with.  Everyone is very nice, and the conditions are very comfortable.
cons: Lack of promotions for my title; little to no growth opportunities.  Once you hit the top of the pay scale, you cannot go up any higher unless you work for a VP.  Too much depends on titles.  Given triple the responsibility with no recognition in pay or promotion.

review_title: Our Mission makes our work important - no matter what job title we have
pros: You know that here, you are contributing to the effort of making a difference for patients with cancer and their families - we have new discoveries all the time that help patients. I think this attracts great people - I have found that people from all different departments here are helpful, friendly, and love working here. And our values (caring, integrity and discovery) are at the forefront of how people make decisions here. The benefits as an employee are great - our leadership shows us that they care about us.
cons: With the importance of the mission, everyone here is busy! Things move fast here; there is not a lot of down time.

review_title: Vision and Mission Driven Work Place
pros: MD Anderson is a very mission and vision-driven workplace. We also appreciate and make a significant effort to create a collaborative culture. Despite the challenges and issues, there is a culture to do the best and to do the right thing. Regardless of your job title, it is a pleasant place to work. You have many exciting opportunities.
cons: You have to remember that this is a State Institution. It is a dynamic place, but it has the elements working under the State Government regulation. The place is massive, close to 20K employees, which is an advantage and disadvantage as a healthcare institute. It is a matter of what is the size of the company do you like to work for.

job_title: Research Data Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: The company is great to their employees. Each department is differently ran but overall, MDA is a great benefits provider and has employee resources that I have never had at any other company:  bonus checks, full size gym, beautiful buildings. I enjoyed working there.
