cons: Most job opportunities at MDA that I found were in the medical center. Traffic is a problem if you work normal business hours. Human Resources is difficult to get in touch with, I usually wait 30 mins on hold for a simple question. Not many cons if you ask me.

review_title: Not all Places are Created Equal
pros: Working at MD Anderson has been one of my greatest experiences ever. The majority of the employees are here for the right reason, the benefits are great, and knowing what you do directly impacts someones life is awesome.
cons: Too many managers have lost focus, and have began to micromanage to achieve the desired goals. Not everyone thrives in this kind of environment, and honestly it has made me want to look for a new position in another department.

review_title: Phenomenal place to work where employees are truly appreciated
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: MD Anderson is such a wonderful place to work because management truly appreciates the employees. I am so happy that I changed my career path when I did and that MD Anderson gave me a great opportunity to work in a patient focused organization.
cons: It's rather tough to list this as a Con, however, there are so many people that want to work here, that it makes it difficult sometimes to obtain a promotion due to the vast amount of competition.

job_title: Patient Service Coordinator in Channelview, TX
pros: Medical insurance is paid for; PTO is given at the end of every month; Department is really good about work/life balance
cons: You have to pay for parking; It is mandatory for you to contribute to TRS;  Unable to use PTO within the first six months; Unable to change department for a year; Pay is not competitive

pros:
- The President is a good leader and inspires us to give excellence service to our patient.
- They make sure that you have an ample training to fulfill your job.
- The benefits are five star
- Salary is very competitive
- HR are very flexible and really listens when you have concerns.
- My AD and Manager are very flexible and inspires us to work harder.
- Parking is great
- Career advancement is very excellent
- Our unit have some exercise equipment you could use.
cons: During ride out, I wish we have better bed and beddings, dedicated shower room for the staff, and better food.

pros: some flexibility in working hours, excellent pay and benefits, institution tries to promote better health among employees with gym, but you can't just join and work out when it suits your schedule, quality scientists and clinicians
cons: like most places, no oversight - upper management allowed to "play games" with staff with no recourse and if you weren't a player, then you stood to suffer some retaliation if you showed signs of resistance (see this at other institutions, too).  It seemed to me that some of the institutional policies gave too much authority to upper management

job_title: Research Assistant II in Houston, TX
pros: Cutting edge research projects with dedicated colleagues, passionate supervisors at state of the art facilities. MD Anderson is a competitive environment with an international reputation for treatments that attract established researchers and academics alike.
cons:
MD Anderson workers suffer from extremely poor mental health, including untreated clinically depressive, anxious, OCD, insomniac and bipolar disorder employees. It is also extremely bureaucratic with below average compensation (compared against MSK, BCM, and enterprise), lots of duplicate research work and wasted resources.

Needless to say, there is plenty of room for improvement that is in sharp contrast with its questionable reputation.

pros: Connecting to the "Mission" is very easy. Seeing the people whose lives we impact is an immensely powerful motivator. In an institution which prides itself on innovative approaches to treatment, innovation in other areas is also appreciated. There are opportunities to move around the organization and/or advance.
cons: Academic Medical Institution "mindset" can, at times, be problematic as standardization and efficiencies from aren't always possible/easy. There's also a history of leading by intimidation and fear.

job_title: Social Work Counselor in Houston, TX
pros: Wonderful management, great work-life balance, highly ethical, fun co-workers, reasonable expectations and workload, utilization of employees is appropriate, your skills are respected and utilized, you get to counsel and educated patients and families, you get free CEUs weekly, free insurance, free gym on a lower level, earlier hours are available to work if needed, free supervision towards LCSW, supportive supervisors, holidays off, paid on-call time, there is a lot of pride in where you are and what you do, patients are wonderful
cons: I really have none. Blessed to be at such a wonderful place.

review_title: As a Radiation Therapist M D Anderson gives you an opportunity to learn a vast number of treatment modalities.
pros:
As an entry level graduatuate you are exposed to a large variety of treatment modalities with the opportunity for advancement.
There is a well structured professional development model.
Benefits and salaries are solid.
MD Anderson's name and reputation facilitates career opportunities 
They offer tuition reimbursement.
Lots of personal growth opportunity through various supplementary programs
cons:
Once you have reached the expert level as a therapist it is difficult to advance within the organization.
The work environment is somewhat political.
Parking is expensive.

review_title: Best Place to Work in Houston Texas
job_title: Senior Cordintor Clinical Studies in Houston, TX
pros: M D Anderson Cancer Center is the best place to work because of their mission-driven company cultures, great benefits, great bosses, great colleagues, and have a great career opportunities. I have been here for almost 25 years and never work somewhere else since I started here.
cons: The downside of working here is having a micromanaging supervisor, stress on workload,  not being recognized or appreciated for your hard work, and working with lazy people.

review_title: Great for cancer care and research, not so great if you're an IT professional
job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: Great benefits/retirement plans, very rewarding to work for the best cancer center in the country, very secure employment, great work-life flexibility, start at 4 weeks vacation/year and increase from there.
cons: Very bureaucratic and top-heavy.  Executive leadership is reactionary and lacks vision.  IT-wise, we're in the dark ages.  IT implementations always run long and over budget, largely due to a lack of talent.  Overstaffed/underskilled.

job_title: Research Assistant I in Houston, TX
pros: There are many opportunities to learn a variety of techniques thanks to their online seminars. The patients are wonderful and give you hope for the every day. It is a very interesting place to work, and you do end up working towards a greater goal which is highly motivating.
cons:
Hard to progress upwards in your field. There is a sense of being back in high school with the cliques and the attitudes between staff members. 
Faculty tend to have an "above it" attitude towards the staff.

job_title: Patient Services Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: Being part of a team is great. Health benefits good.  Patients are our # 1 priority.  Interaction with patients is wonderful.  Love the job, love the people !  Lots of room for  improvement though !
cons:
I have been working for MDACC for 8 years !  
No career pathway. Pay is poor for the amount of responsibility and workload.  Can be very stressful when dealing with bad management decisions.  Demerit point system if tardy or call in.  No sick leave, comes out of your vacation time.  Pay for own parking.  For the #1 Cancer Institute in the country, treatment of staff is poor.  Morale is very low at the moment and staff resignations are on the increase.

pros: Good benefits and retirement plan.  Clean and new work environments.  Well known brand name for your resume.  Good work-life balance.
cons: No promotion growth and really hard to transfer to another department.  Management is full of nepotism and lacking respect towards CPAs.  Their mission emphasizes "Caring" values but they don't practice this towards their employees.  Here, it doesn't matter how intelligent and hard you work, if management doesn't like you, then you are out of luck.  People with the wrong attitude and poor management style get promoted over you.  Human Resources is full of red-tape bureaucrats and make impossible demands that you be the same people person as everyone else.  Once you become a senior accountant, then it's time to leave.  Staying here too long can hurt your career.

review_title: It was mix of good and bad
job_title: Research Assistant II in Houston, TX
pros: I could work on hi-fi research at a faster pace. Work on several projects at the same time. The first year was very good.
cons:
Despite MD Anderson being the best place to work, My professor was showed no encouragement and appreciation for the efforts. Also the friday group meetings are a nightmare. There was also personal bias and racial discrimination involved. Your job satisfaction fell so bad lots of times - I believe this totally depends on who your mentor is.
However, MD anderson as a whole is the best place to be employed

review_title: Follow up to a previous post by former faculty member
pros: It was a privilege taking care of patients at MD Anderson. Some of my faculty colleagues were truly interested in providing exceptional patient care. A significant percentage, however, seemed more interested in recruiting patients for clinical trials funded by the pharmaceutical industry and padding their CV's with committee work in order to obtain promotions.
cons: An inordinate amount of red tape exists at this institution. It takes way too long to get a new idea accomplished. By the time a new idea has been presented at the multiple committee meetings deemed necessary for its implementation, the new idea is old. Since leaving MD Anderson, I have heard multiple complaints from many patients regarding their care there.

pros: MD Anderson has excellent educational opportunities,  great benefits, and competitive pay.  They encourage professional growth and excellence in service to the community.
cons: The culture is unduly political and extremely partial.  Promotions and hiring are based on preference of the hiring manager rather than qualifications of the candidate and departamental management often practice favoritism which goes ignored by upper management and HR.  At MDA your promotion is based on "who you know" rather than "what you know"

pros: MD Anderson pays well. You have state benefits. The food in the cafeterias is good. There are many friendly, sweet patients and families.
cons:
If you are a conservative, Christian, pro-life heterosexual, (and dare I say, Caucasian) all of the inclusion campaigns don't include you. When I didn't join in the Trump-bashing, I was ostracized. I knew a few other conservatives in different departments, and they also felt out-of-place in their areas, and even when they don't say a word, demoralized.
Every few years, out-of-control spending has resulted in layoffs. Six months later, they're back hiring and building again. It's really too much.

review_title: The Pro's and Con's of Being Big
pros: As each of us in one way or another who know or has known someone with cancer, we as employees are here because we do believe in our mission - to eliminate cancer.  For non-patient care staff, the work / life balance provides a variety of options.  Due to the size of MD Anderson, one can transfer into a different field without leaving the hospital.
cons: On the reverse side of the 'size' coin, MD Anderson's growth has buildings and staff away from the patient care areas.  Working in or near patient care areas, you are reminded as to the reason you work at MD Anderson.

review_title: Anderson is an institution with some talented researchers and physicians but plagued by a slow and inept bureaucracy.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: Flexible schedules, great diversity of opportunities, decent benefits, equitable and widespread information technology access, great research library, interesting invited speakers.
cons: Inconvenient and expensive parking, numerous unprofessional colleagues, unending compliance requirements, crippling bureaucracy, inadequate compensation, cramped working spaces, fractured information technology support.

review_title: Sexism, cruelty, and favoritism in management is a HUGE problem in some areas.
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: The benefits are amazing and you get the sense that the jobs are stable. Unless a lab loses funding and your position/salary is contingent upon a grant, you can be assured of a place at the institution. They like to hire from within so moving to a new department is relatively easy, and while management isn't great the camaraderie that you come to feel towards patients, families, and co-workers is second to none.
cons:
I worked in a group where blatant sexism, cruelty, and favoritism were often overlooked. I put up with regular disgusting comments and, when I dared to reject/rebuff them, genuinely uncalled-for and awful remarks about my job performance from the scientific manager in the group I worked in. I was blamed for things that weren't my fault and systematically "othered" and pushed out after enduring months of abuse which, when elevated to more senior managers, was not dealt with appropriately. He suffered no repercussions and I was made to feel as though I had to leave. 

I was asked to work overtime without pay more than once, but I refused to clock out. I was expected to always be available to answer emails and calls, to scrub in for 5 am surgeries and collect specimens, to stay late processing and enrolling and doing paperwork -- but then got in trouble for going over on my standard hours and forcing the department to pay me overtime. Overall I consistently had far more put on my plate than any one employee should be expected to handle. It was a toxic and unsupportive environment. 

Great place if you need a stable job with good benefits that pays the bills, not great if you care about career advancement and your own mental health. Especially not great if you're a junior female employee.

pros: Great benefits.  Excellent office facilities.   Noble mission.   Good compensation.   Friendly co-workers.   Lots of good, honest work to be done here.
cons: Poor hiring practices, especially for management positions.   Some managers and directors are abusive of their staff and do not know how to manage people or projects.   Chronic understaffing in certain areas, especially in the IS division.  Upper management in complete chaos.

review_title: Great place to work, but find other ways to hone your skillset
job_title: Senior Applications Systems Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: Great people, benefits were good, and you can take pride in knowing that your contributions are helping realize a greater good...
cons: i would say health care is second only to government for embracing technology and its applications...  its most likely the industry erring on the side of caution, but that's not going to help you sharpen your underutilized development skills when your hired to maintain an environment that a consulting firm packaged up for the hospital.

pros: Great co-workers, who for the most part work as a team and are GREAT at what they do. Lots of compassion for the patients.
cons: Staff is disrespected and unappreciated by management, work hours are long and though they say they promote work-life balance, try getting any time off (that you have earned) to spend with your family or go to see your Dr. We were constantly told that we needed to see more patients and do more procedures.

pros: I love working here at MD Anderson. The people I work with make me feel like family we are family. MD Anderson offers so much to us as employees. I enjoy coming to work everyday and doing my job. Helping anyway I can,  my co-workers, my boss or our patients that is why we are here to help our patients anyway we can, from getting to their appointments or even just to listen to them even if it's just a hug they need.
cons: There is nothing that I can say is wrong here at MD Anderson.

pros: You get to work with some really great people. Great retirement benefits and pretty good work life balance if you have a good manager.
cons: We're hesitant to do try new ways of doing things to streamline the beauracracy. Faculty can be difficult to work for. Administrative managers are more obsessed with petty rules than fostering the work and creativity of individuals. That's necessary for nurses and office support staff but not so great for professionals. New "open concept" office environment is not conducive to productivity.

review_title: Challenging work environment with limited growth
pros:
Challenging 
Multi cultural 
Good teamwork 
Great employee resources/training 
Excellent benefits (medical is free - dental/vision $40 roughly per month) 
Employee perks
cons:
Limited growth: many assistants train or perform senior or exclusive assistant roles with no salary/title change. 

Most coworkers haven't been promoted in over five years. 

High turn over. 

Hard to switch into a different field. 

Coworkers lack education (only one of two with college education) 

Coworkers tend to be a little more rough around the edges

job_title: Senior Research Nurse in Houston, TX
pros: Working with the patients is the bomb for me, they are all so sweet and gracious. Also, they have the latest technology on most everything as far as tools to get your job done. There are lots of good friends here. They pay well. The benefits are great.
cons: Since they are so big, it takes too long for some things to get done. Supervisors in the department do not use the discipline process well, they either ignore it or over-use it. They should have more training so you can know what to expect.

review_title: Great Job, but still an enormous facility
pros: Love the people I work with directly on a day-to-day basis and even those on a less frequent basis.
cons: Due to the sheer size of the place--will sometimes have to encounter and work with someone outside or above your department.  You have little recourse or say if they want to make certain changes, very hierarchical.   Some serious political issues between high-end staff that really only effects others indirectly.  Every hospital is going to have highly trained, highly paid individuals who act like children when they dont get their way, but overall I do respect most people at this facility.

pros: They pay for school. I have almost completed  my FNP without paying a penny. Most people are in school so management is very accommodating. Good units to work on are the hematology units. Surgery floors are less funded. Amazing patient nurse ratio. 1:4 on med surg; 1:2 or 3 hematology units.
cons: Very focused on customer service- sometimes to the detriment of patient care. Still very nursing centered, but has lessened over the years. Don't work in the ICU- very depressing. Basically torturing people who should be in hospice.

review_title: University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center
pros: Great work environment, very good benefits, PTO time is above average.  Co-workers are very positive.   We have a great team and enjoy coming to work.
cons: TOO MANY MEETINGS!!!  We have meetings about meetings!  Some are very unskilled at leading a meeting and keeping on track (agenda).  I waste 20% of my time every week in worthless meetings.  Why aren't we using WEBEX MORE???

pros: Pay, benefits, and support for all staff is wonderful.  I really love the new era MD Anderson is in with our new president and high reliability focus.   There is so many wonderful resources for staff to grow and learn.  The people who work here are phenomenal and care about year other--we are a family.
cons: The commute is tough.  Living near the medical center is not financially feasible to most, so the drive can be rough at times.

pros: Overall genuine concern and passion for patient care. Large population of patients is still cared for. State benefits, retirement plan and good healthcare benefits. Good for longevity.
cons: POLITICS, self serving motives, general sense of trust between employees is low. Highly bureaucratic environment. Top level leadership has a faded sense of reality and even lower understanding of the challenges facing IT employees in particular.  Not sure there is a desire by leadership to understand real issues. Bonus driven leadership creates low morale in a highly stressful environment.

review_title: Management Either Clueless or Doesn't Care
pros:
•	Free Fitness Center on-site
•	Benefits (healthcare, retirement) are good
•	Quick increase in number of PTO days per year based on length of employment at institution
•	Changing positions internally is not frowned upon; a surprising number of employees in many positions came from another position within the institution
cons:
•	No progression for high achievers; spend enough time and get promoted; slow career and salary growth if you stay; lots of talent ends up leaving
•	Lack of telecommuting option or highly restricted telecommuting for IT positions
•	Lack of follow-through by management; say one thing, do another; example – committee of employees convened to discuss why morale is so low and nothing ever came of the committee’s results
•	Feeling that management says they care but actually do not. Morale has been low for over a year (since the 10% layoff) and the few things that have been done are like bandages on a severed artery.
•	Over-reliance on contractors who receive telecommute rights and higher pay than actual employees while remaining at the institution well past the ends of their projects 
•	Loyalty to the institution is not valued
•	Time tracking of salaried employees is required and monitored for some departments
•	Decision-making and project approvals are very political
•	Must pay for parking in hospital-owned garage

pros:
1). Working for the #1 Cancer center in the world.
2). Benefits to include: insurance, paid time off, holidays.
3). My co-workers
cons: Only one I can think of is: That annual merits aren't given after a certain time of the year, when a promotion is accepted. Unless, the promotion increase is of a certain percentage, a person should be given their annual merit for their work done during the previous year and for their previous contributions to offset the small promotion percentage increase.

review_title: I enjoy working for the company
pros: There are great opportunities and support for career advancement depending on the area that you are in.  The quest for knowledge is appreciated here and majority of the people who work here really love what they do.
cons: This hospital houses a lot of highly skilled and highly educated professionals, so it can be difficult to obtain optimal job.  So many apply and so many are qualified.  Since this is a larger hospital, the work load is a lot more than some other institutions who may pay virtually the same salaries.

review_title: World renowned institution but hardly impressive.
pros:
Benefits are awesome! 
Having MDA a previous employer on your resume usually impresses other employers  because of MDA's reputation. 
MDA employs somewhere around 20k employees! You will be able to network at a magnitude level. 
I have learned so much from working at MDA. You learn to troubleshoot and use the array of resources the institution has to offer.
cons:
Contrary to popular beliefs, MDA does not pay that well compared to other institutions in the medical center. Of course, this will vary on your position. I left to go to UT and got a $15k raise! 
The parking is expensive and there are so many buildings. Expect to commute often within the institution. Arrive at least 20 minutes before you have to clock in.
I worked for two different departments and went on numerous interviews, growth is difficult in MDA. I finally got promoted to another department and only got a $3000 increase. They also have to meet a quota for interviews, meaning they will interview individuals even if they already have someone in mind to hire.  
I will admit, customer service at MDA is pretty low because the patients are pretty aggressive and abusive. I have had a pager thrown at me from a patient! I have seen numerous physical altercations between patients! 
The culture here is "who" you know and not "what" you know. People will get promoted because of their relationships with others. 
There are many slackers here and it is difficult to get fired from a state institution so expect to do the work of others. 
Their evaluation system is a joke.  Management (that barely interacts with you) will evaluate your yearly performance which affects your merit. 
Low morale throughout the institution. People usually stay with MDA because of their benefits but other UT institutions have very similar benefits. 
Their payroll is confusing! You will hardly receive the same check because of the way they calculate their payroll. Also, OT gets paid two weeks behind.

job_title: Fire Sprinkler Technician (Javi L Taylor #209469) in Houston, TX
pros: Most of the time, MD Anderson prides themselves on integrity, honesty, respect, love, compassion , peace, kindness, righteousness, loyalty, upright merit, grace, mercy, and the will to sincerely take care of all their patients and employees.  Most of the time, MD Anderson listens to the needs of their patients and staff.  Most of MD Anderson's management staff takes the time to get involved in directing and guiding  their employees through the tasks of caring for the institution. Most of  MD Anderson's management staff with great effort, participates in practicing the institution's core values in every situation possible.. MD Anderson in most cases, respect their employees federal, state and work place rights.  In most cases, MD Anderson takes pride to create a positive and safe working environment for their staff.  While we are all humans, it is impossible to create a 100% flawless working environment, however, in most cases, MD Anderson does give great effort in trying to do so...
cons: MD Anderson is a very large institution.  Sometimes critical issues, problems and or concerns of their employees and patients may take a while to be noticed and or recognized.  Also, MD Anderson, like any other large institution, can always improve on various methods in which the staff can keep a healthy form of swift and efficient communication between each other.

pros: MD Anderson is a place that will allow their employees to advance.  The process may be slow, but it worth the wait.  They pay top dollar for your services and the benefits are really great.
cons: The down side to this is HR take a long time to process your paperwork.  They are a great group of people, but the time it take to get things done is needing improvement.

pros: prestige, famous, big, comprehensive, patient appreciation, recognition, relatively higher pay than peers in the same city, good facility, appears rich
cons: slow, a lot of waste of money, the quality of research doesn't really fit with the fame, bureaucratic, management ignorant

job_title: Summer Intern in Sugar Land, TX
pros: I learned more during this internship than I ever have in during a 3 month span. Everyone, including the high ups, were very accessible and always ready to help. This really is a teaching hospital, and I couldn't speak more highly of my experience. I was never left hanging and was constantly asked how and if my experience could be improved. A great place to intern for anyone interested in research and medicine.
cons: There really are none I experienced as an intern.

review_title: Good Company in General...  BAD Executive Management
pros: Its a good place to be employed with competitive salary, good benefits flexible hours and generally decent people to work with.
cons:
Top Management are awful business people so every few years the organization goes thru a fiscal crisis of its own making.
They tend to promote and hire people that are not particularity competent, that way they are not a threat to jobs of the people who hired them.

job_title: IT Senior Specialist in Houston, TX
pros: My experience has been Managers main responsibility is to grow their direct reports. The institution works hard to develop a career path that meets your and the institution's needs.  You ask and they listen and try hard to put you in the best position to succeed.
cons: Need to develop better way to award yearly merit commensurate with work accomplished.

job_title: Senior Technical Writer in Houston, TX
pros: Recently, I have been afforded the opportunity to use my background experience to further develop the work processes in my department.  I find the work challenging and rewarding.  In short I like coming to work.
cons: We are undergoing some growing pains right now which is actually good. We are expanding and updating our technological and research resources to continue to advance the fight to make cancer history.

pros: The staff is lives the core values of caring, integrity and discovery!  There is a fantastic sense of hope among staff and patients.  The administration is supportive and makes everyone feel that they are making cancer history.  They are building a huge gym for employees to support healthy-lifestyles.
cons: There are no downsides!  I should really pay them to allow me the honor of working with such an amazing team of people.

review_title: M.D. Anderson is a nice place for Doctors and Scientist.
pros: M.D. Anderson is in Houston's medical center area where as a scientist one can cooprate not only inside the institution but also outside the institution, such as Baylor college of Medicine, HSC at houston, UT medical branch, Rice University.
cons: As a researcher, one need to cooperate within and outside the institue. Some time outside coopration save lots of time and efforts. Most of the cases P.I. took that initiative. The fellow set behind.

pros: It's a great place to work.  I loved it.  I enjoy the fast pace environment and loved seeing the faces on patients that have be cured or in remission of their cancer.  I enjoyed working on major projects for physician attending seminars, conferences.  The benefits were great and MD Anderson take very good care of their employees,
cons: I really don't have any cons to share.  It was a good work environment, and I looked forward to going to work everyday,

job_title: IT Senior Project Manager in Houston, TX
pros: Many wonderful co-workers and a mission near and dear to my heart.
cons: I can only speak for the department where I work... immediate leadership out of touch and reluctant to address issues. Employees often feel discounted and ignored. Lack of adherence to generally recognized industry standards in favor of quick fixes and making our supervisors 'look good'.

review_title: Great place to work with Pension!
job_title: Senior EHR Sys Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: Open door policy, institution transparency, executives are approachable, coworkers are generally genuine, great core values and president is awesome.
cons: Micro-managing, major redundancy in documentation, technology leaves a bit to be desired, constant system updates which slows or stops work, connectivity issues on-site and away, HR notifies and shares with management if you call them, promotion process is more of a must apply for job and interview with peers and manager panels and then a 'new job acceptance' meeting with HR. If you have to interview for a 'promotion', why not look elsewhere since you're interviewing.

pros: Positive changing culture from silos to more inclusive and collaborative. Great benefit package. Competitive salary. Fantastic mission and reason to come to work every day.
cons: Senior leaders are excellent, but treat middle-management on a "need to know" basis sometimes.  Have to pay to park. Hard to really achieve a true work-life balance.  This is possibly a healthcare thing as opposed to MDA though.

review_title: MD Anderson is overall a great working environment with great health benefits.
pros: Health Benefits are great.  There are campus police that help you feel safe, especially if you have to stay over hours.
cons: No down sides for this particular company, well, maybe one, that is that you have to pay for your parking space.

review_title: Good place for starters and getting some experience
job_title: Behavioral Science Research Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: Tuition reimbursement; insurance; parking; healthy food options
cons: management; micromanaging; want you to work 45 hrs without flex time; for a promotion you can only get a 15% increase at max of your current salary (which usually puts you at the minimum range of the new position). Staff is underpaid and management is overpaid; bonuses and rewards always go to upper management, rarely is it given to staff. High turnover rate.

pros: They are doing great work, and there is a push towards improving issues with upper level administration (search for new president, attempts to get feedback from all employees in the process of making adjustments to how the organization is governed, etc.).  Benefits are OK. (Note--I see De Pinho is still listed as CEO, but he's been gone for months now.)
cons: I'd give  2.5 stars overall, if I could.  I can only speak for the "instructor" (non-tenure track research "faculty") position, which in reality is  just a post-post-doc. Because this is not a tenure track position, opportunities for obtaining funding and advancing are limited. As with most academic positions, any real advancement in terms of salary, title, etc. can be painfully slow. (Of course, this may vary by dept.)  Salary is too low for the level of education/experience, and given recent budget issues, I have to wonder if it will improve much anytime soon. I joined because I really wanted to work on a specific project, but honestly, I am having doubts about staying.

pros: I had the chance to work with smart researchers. The offices are big and quite. There is a fitness center for free for the ones who works out regularly.
cons: Compensation is lower than the other places. Any paperwork takes long time inside the institution. The administrative personnel is not responsive to our concerns. Had to chance to see my advisor very rarely and briefly.

review_title: Being employed with MD Anderson was amazing. Best job I've had.
pros: The pay was good, considering I do not have a degree. The benefits package was amazing. The perks you receive as a employee. The mission of MD Anderson is phenomenal.
cons: The medical center is horrible! The streets and traffic are bad! Working with employees who have degrees tend to look down on employees without degrees. Some are snooty and stuck up. Some managers do not know how to manage an office. The department I was employed with there was some favoritism of other employees which in my opinion was unprofessional.

pros: Great coworkers laid back job, just do your job and you will be fine. Defiantly one of the most diverse places one could possibly work.
cons: upper management at times lack the proper project management skills needed to make a project go as efficiently as possible.

pros: great environment for someone who has a passion for learning, fast paced, coworkers are all well educated and overall enjoyable to work with, great benefits, excellent hospital overall
cons: not enough responsibilities, responsibilities that are given are miniscule and don't require any thought, lack of appreciation or acknowledgment, poor yearly raises, micromanaging, high stress environment causes discrepancies between coworkers

review_title: MD Anderson Cancer Center is geting better
job_title: Environmental Health and Safety Specialist in Houston, TX
pros:
1. Commitment to elimination of cancer.
2. Career growth opportunities because roles change as needed to achieve goals.
3. Personal growth opportunities because the institution promotes continuing education and training.
4. Institutional commitment to improvement at all levels.
5. Great pay and benefits over long-term when you stay at the institution.
cons:
1. Size of institution makes finding specific people for specific situations tedious. 
2. Communication issues between groups/departments that do not partner together regularly.

pros: Mission of "Making Cancer History" and the "Moon Shot" research projects are easy to get behind, but its the patients who are truly inspiring and who make it worth getting up and going to work every day.
cons: Ivory tower leadership can be elitist and there are a lot of political wars that do nothing but slow the already-slow process of getting things done through the UT System. Also, negotiate the salary you want going in, because raises are miniscule along the way, also thanks to UT.

review_title: I am working at MD Anderson
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Sugar Land, TX
pros: Best people around you, and you can gain experience quickly. All kinds of data you would encounter here, which you would not see somewhere else. This unique experience add more value for your future career.
cons: Too big a company, and sometime you will get lost easily. While you stay here long enough, you will know them at least for people in the same department

pros: MD Anderson employees are committed to our patients and each other in a way that is different than other organizations or hospitals.  You can feel it walking through the halls and interacting with the staff.  Even though we have over 20,000 employees, we all work in unison to fight cancer every day.
cons: We work very hard and at a very fast pace, no matter the area of the hospital.  It isn't a "con" necessarily, it can just take some getting used to if you are accustomed to working at a slower speed.

job_title: Senior Clinical Studies Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: I have been in the field for about 20 years and of all my years of work this is the best place I have ever worked.  MD Anderson treats all employees as if they are the most important part of the company no matter what the position they hold.  MD Anderson not only cares about their patients but they also care about each employee.
cons: The only thing negative I have to say is I wish there was more parking.

review_title: great carrer in a down economy
pros: Excellent benefits including State of Texas Teachers Retirement for everyone, plus a month of Paid Time Off your first year.  Easy going atmosphere.  The focus here really is on the patients, you can do whatever you need to do to help them, and management won't question you.
cons: Lots of dead weight.  No one ever gets fired.  People call in sick constantly and never get reprimanded for it.  Rarely see or here from management.  Sometimes can feel invisible here.

pros: Excellent Retirement and PTO Benefits
cons: MicroManaged, No Room for advancement, Benefical to those who have cush office jobs, not to the employee who works in clinic with patients, and most of all PDM!!! It's all about money and being in the black.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros:
- Great resources, top of the line equipment
- Opportunities for clinical collaboration
- Access to UT BCBS health plan
cons:
- Emphasis is on publications over actual clinical implementation
- PhD students are very restricted in their opportunities. There are virtually no options for a PhD student to gain any non-academic experience (e.x., for industry jobs)
- PhD students are considered "part-time" and are compensated for a nominal 20 hours a week, when, in reality, they regularly work 60 hours/week.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: There is so much growth available form an employee at MD Anderson. I was initially hired 4 years ago as a scheduler and have received 2 promotions since. I recently initiated my new role as Senior Administrative Assistant.  Mentoring is strong encouraged across the institution and easily made available. Great benefits, insurance and time off! Employee appreciation is a huge part of the MDA culture.
cons: Having to pay for parking is definitely a con but this applies to any facility in the Texas Medical Center.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Houston, TX
pros: MD Anderson truly cares about ALL of their employees; it shows in their inclusive events and many awards highlighting exceptional patient care.  Their research is ahead of the game with clinical trials that no other hospital has taken on.
cons: I don't feel we get enough good press about the technology and research that we do here.  Our commercials just so people saying that we here to end cancer but don't highlight all the equipment and trials that we have in our arsenal.

review_title: Huge career opportunity but you are a very small fish in very big ocean!
pros:
Amazing career opportunities
Good for learning new skills and keep on improving overall profile
Access to very extensive resources
Feels like you are making contribution to the noble cause
cons:
You are not given due credit for your work
For postdoctoral fellow, their development depends on their mentors but most of them are too busy to take time for you, but exceptions are everywhere

job_title: Operations Coordinator in Sugar Land, TX
pros: Getting to work with great people, meeting and talking to patients trying to make there time with MD Anderson as enjoyable as possible. Benefits and pay is wonderful.
cons: I really don't have a down side working here, I have so many loving stories with co-workers

review_title: Company Review MD Anderson Cancer Center
pros: Finding a cure for Cancer, Great Pay, Helping the Patients, Great Co-workers.
cons: Upper Management does not follow-up on what lower management is doing to or treating the employees.  Lower management has too much power to do whatever they want.

review_title: Dynamic, fast-paced environment that places its top priority on patient care and patient services.
job_title: Research Assistant II in Houston, TX
pros: The benefits are probably the best in the Texas Medical Center, and the hours are usually properly structured and managed.
cons:
The opportunities for raises and/or advancement are very strictly structured and follow very specific guidelines, so while it's not impossible to move up and/or branch out, it takes a very long time. 

It is very difficult to branch out into/learn about any area which does not EXACTLY match your specific job's description.

pros: Great opportunities and benefits for employees. Very thorough training for employees and great HR department. I was a temporary employee, an extern at one of their research centers but I would love to come back as a full time employee.
cons: Early hours and some unprofessional coworkers but overall easy way to earn good money working for a good company

review_title: A dream place for cancer researchers
pros: State-of-art facilities, exceptional patient care, very collaborative environment. People here are very nice and helpful. Great culture and diversity, good benefit. IT support here is wonderful. A lot of great researchers are here and many more are invited here for talk. There are many workshops and training opportunities for trainee.
cons: Many rules here are stubborn and very complicated. Paper work is quite tedious and takes very long time to process. Sometimes you have to push really hard to get things done.

job_title: Patient Services Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros:
I love caring for patients and assisting them.
They have great benefits.
cons:
Management is horrible.
Management is inconsiderate and will overwhelm you with no regard for what's already on your plate.
In my department there is favoritism.
There isn't much room for advancement or ability transfer to other departments.
The pay is not the best. Other hospitals in TMC pay more
Morale is down and they do nothing to bring it up.

review_title: overall positive experience with room for improvement
pros: For researchers, the resources are first-rate including core facilities with the latest technologies. There are also numerous internal funding opportunities to support departments, core facilities, and individual investigators. The proximity to patients makes for a very motivating environment.
cons: The bureaucracy can be very thick (depending on one's specific role and one-up), making it difficult to get things done quickly and also to get promoted, even for high performing individuals under good leaders advocating for them. Also, public transportation is lacking, and parking is expensive and/or inconvenient.

job_title: Advanced Practice Nurse in Houston, TX
pros: The working environment at MD Anderson promotes growth. Every employee is valued and whatever their responsibilities are, it is always aligned to the mission of the hospital. Of course, the benefits are great!
cons: Because of the recent surveys from several agencies, the employees especially individuals who are involved in direct patient care, are feeling the pressure and the demands of the several changes in their workflow. Otherwise, the hospital is always a great place to work.

pros:
You can learn a lot and every one next to you is a genius.
Your colleagues will be all friendly
cons:
only good if you are on clinical track, much harder if you are on research track. You can even sense the attitude from the nurse that they are not very respectful even to researchers.

Very slow HR

Heavy political hassle across the different departments, but I guess that's common in a big institution.

Sponsorship affair to VISA holder are poor

pros: Colleagues are topnotch and for the most part, generous and helpful. The institution's mission is clear, and every employee is made to feel that their contribution is important. Benefits and compensation are good. There was a strong sense of camaraderie on my team.
cons: Resources for training and development were sometimes hard to come by in my (non-patient facing) department.

job_title: Lead Patient Service Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: Benefits are worthwhile, time off is reasonable, and opportunities are endless if you know the right people.
cons: Management isn't supportive, their expectations far outweigh what they are willing to pay and the office politics is far beyond what is necessary in a hospital for cancer patients.

job_title: Senior Clinical Studies Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: There are many resources in supporting work life balance. Such as gym, employee assistance program, cancer screening tests for life.  And IT service,  well design homepage,  online and in class education program for work.
cons: The time clock breaks the moral in our workforce.  A minute more or less does not necessary contribute to the productivity. Exempt and non exempt employee provide segregation. I decided to change department since my pervious department has its own guideline of tardiness thought I never been late once.

job_title: Grant Programs Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: The organizational culture is excellent and rich with diversity and inclusiveness. MD Anderson sponsors numerous employee network organizations, including Organization for Women, Organization for Multicultural Employees, and LGBT Organization. There are many training opportunities for self and career development. MD Anderson also has a robust and structured mentorship program that provides great networking opportunities and help guide employees to career development and mobility within the organization.
cons: When applicable, employees should get work schedule and workspace flexibility.  This is known to increase employee loyalty, happiness, and productivity.

pros: incredible access to patient volume and diverse array of resources in terms of translational science  collaborators.   Good support administratively  Gym in the Pickens Tower is an amazing benefit
cons:
State mentality makes it difficult sometimes to get things done
too many layers of bureaucrats managing those of us who actually produce

review_title: MD ANDERSON IS THE PLACE TO RETIRE FROM
pros: MD Anderson Cancer Center is one of the best places to work.  The institution is rewarding, the benefits are great.  The atmosphere is and work environment is great and they really care about their employees.
cons: Although this is the top rated facility in the world some of the compensation policy need to be reviewed.   Advancement is not as easy as one would think.

review_title: Good experience on the research arm of the institution, but my PI had adequate funding for my entire appointment.
pros: As a research appointment, there is a strong motivation being housed in the hospital with exposure to patients and their families. The core facilities (sequencing, histology, vet med) are all top notch. The compliance and grant offices are responsive to questions and willing to help.
cons: Departmental support is variable. Adequate external funding is a must for continued work. Neither of these are isolated to MDACC, but both do occur here.

pros: medical insurance free for employee only
cons: Upper Management sucks! A lot of favoritism, if you are not part of the kiss butt team, you will have lot of problems with upper management. Upper management like to pick on you even if you're doing your work and meeting productivity. Don't come here PBS 8th floor

job_title: Lead Care Manager in Houston, TX
pros:
A shared commitment to our mission to end cancer
An atmosphere that supports career advancement
An institution committed to innovation in research and clinical practice
Feeling you are part of something larger than yourself that is contributing to the well being of others
cons: Large infrastructure can sometimes make decisions cumbersome and difficult to make in a timely manner

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: Great benefits, very structured and organized. I worked for here for 5years met great people and the Doctors are truly passionate about what they do!
cons: Do research on departments before you accept some departments have poor management. It's more of who you know rather than your qualifications for jobs be mindful of this.

review_title: Would have helped to had adequate training
pros:
Good name recognition
Good pay and benefits
Nice cafeteria
Nice looking building
A lot of potential opportunities throughout the hospital
cons:
Training was horrible
Little patience shown toward learning curve
Lack of staffing
Rude and impatient doctor to work with 
lack of flexibility in scheduling
My shoe had more people skills then one of the doctors I worked with

job_title: Materials Management Supervisor in Houston, TX
pros:
Benefits are wonderful
People who work here are great
The reason we are all here is worth it
cons:
Paying for parking increases each year as less and less options for it become open
IF you are hesitant to work somewhere you might been deemed essential staff during acclimate weather or emergencies then this place is not for you.  It is a 24/7/365 environment.
State job.  State politics can affect the day to day operations.

job_title: Certified Registered Nurse Anesthetist in Houston, TX
pros: Challenging cases, competitive hourly rate, 100% healthcare paid,  plenty of breaks throughout the day, minimal to no call required, weekends and holidays off.
cons: Parking can cost up to $2000 a year, overtimenis only paid over 80 hours, no premium time compensation if staying over shift, no compensation for taking Call, heavy MDA supervision.

review_title: I have been working at M. D. Anderson Cancer Center full-time for more than 4 years
pros: As a research appointment, there is a strong motivation being housed in the hospital with exposure to patients and their families. The core facilities (sequencing, histology, vet med) are all top notch. The compliance and grant offices are responsive to questions and willing to help.
cons: Departmental support is variable. Adequate external funding is a must for continued work. Neither of these are isolated to MDACC, but both do occur here.

pros: Interesting work, great mission, good people, good benefits and pay.
cons: Career paths are not clear and promotions can be hard to come by.

pros: Benefits are good, they have a good retirement. Most employees were nice to work with and helpful.
cons: Pay is laughable for the workload. Overworked and underpaid. Micromanaging at its finest. Management staff is terrible. Parking is very high!  Administrative pay is very low to start off with even if you have years of extensive experience. Cheap place all around they don't even provide coffee.

pros: Benefits are great! Great job security!
cons: If you consider applying at MD Anderson, consider to contact the head/director directly. The HR system is not well organized and they do not forward the appropriate applications to the directors/heads. HR is not well responsive and does not provide any updates on your submitted application.

review_title: If you want to feel like you're making a difference in the world, this place is for you.
pros: great colleagues, excellent benefits, active effort to make employees happy by upper management
cons: middle management likes the status quo, garage parking is costly, work can be emotionally draining if you deal with patients

pros:
This institution has a good reputation in cancer research field, and is ambitious to make cancer history. Many new trials seem on going. 
Basic science researchers have some chances to work with clinicians. 
Employees have good benefits.
cons:
It is not like a formal position, and is viewed as a trainee under a Professor's instruction/supervision. 
A postdoc can not work longer than a certain years. (5 in our situation)
Salary is relatively low.

review_title: Top patient care but research can be better!
pros:
Offers great patient care
Healthcare benefits to employees
Added value to CV
cons:
Not all groups have these cons, however, the group I worked with had
 hierarchy
politics
Clinicians get recognized more than the actual researcher
You are easily replaceable if you are on an immigrant visa, despite good performance

review_title: overall, good place to be a Pharmacist
pros:
innovative drug therapies, fast-paced workload; challenging and motivating
good wook schedules, flexible scheduling available; overtime frequently offered
competitive salary with good benefits
cons: weak upper management; failure to deal with problem employees; HR is worthless, in that all it does is to worry about not getting sued, so it takes decades to fire a bad worker.

review_title: Great organization, outstanding care for patients
pros: Provides extremely high quality care to patients, and the majority of  employees take pride in their work and mission. The opportunities for contributing to research and patient care are unparalleled.
cons: MDACC is a very large cancer center and for some that can be overwhelming. As an employee, it may be difficult to stand out.

review_title: M.D. Anderson is a great institution dedicated to curing cancer
job_title: Instructor Research Faculty Appointment in Smithville, TX
pros: Stable company with outstanding leadership and strong core values. Annual reviews foster career development. Institutional survey's encourage change as needed. Pleasant work colleagues and professional support.
cons: Difficult to promote through the ranks in academia from postdoc to Asst. Professor, but opportunities are still available.

pros: Top notch research environment in terms of access to expertise and technology
cons: Very bureaucratic and can often run into advisers/management that have old school mentality that leaning hard on people is the best way to get work done without treating the employee as a person

pros: MD Anderson is an amazing institution to work for. The growth opportunities are endless here. MDACC provides avenues for its employees to develop personally and professionally while contributing to the number on goal - making cancer history. I love working here, I love my department and the team that surrounds me. I love the fact that teams are empowered to contribute to decision making in my department. To add, the benefits are great!!!
cons: I really have no cons to list!

review_title: A place ideal for those who are interested in academic career
pros: Here you can work with smart researchers/scholars/clinicians, who may come from different countries and devote their lives in cancer-related researches. Meetings/symposium are held quite often, revealing new treatments/discovery. Academic atmosphere is very strong.
cons: Salary is limited by funding and mostly lower than expected. Also you can not stay in this position too long because it has a limit of years. Long work hours may be required, but it also depends on labs.

job_title: Senior IT Project Manager in Houston, TX
pros: MD Anderson Cancer Center performs amazing studies in cancer research leading to cancer treatments that have extended and enriched the lives of individuals around the globe.
cons: Research Funding:  MD Anderson Cancer research is extremely expensive requiring years of dedicated research studies before desired results are achieved.  Without the essential research funding cures within grasp may be delayed while individuals that could benefit from the cures continue to perish.

review_title: A great place for career advancing opportunities
job_title: Clinical Research Project Manager in Houston, TX
pros: career advancement opportunities, mentoring, leadership building, culture of care, culture of hope, good benefits, work-life balance is promoted.
cons: sub-culture in different departments may not represent the true spirit of the institution; can be highly political

job_title: Clinical Cell Therapy Specialist in Houston, TX
pros:
-The work was challenging, but not exceedingly difficult.  
-It was fulfilling knowing that I was actively saving lives with my work.
-The people were mostly nice to work with.
-Benefits were great.
-Generally a laid-back yet productive environment
cons:
-The pay was much too low. This is the only real reason I left.
-The parking situation was ridiculous. 
-The food was expensive and not very good
-Promotions were difficult to come by

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: Great collaborative environment and resources for developing clinically significant cancer research. Positions include basic health insurance and retirement benefits. Great resources for career development.
cons: No economic parking options, and food choices. No dental or vision insurance provided but optional to add on to health insurance.

review_title: Amazing place for employees and patients
pros: The mission to cure cancer has recruited some of the best and brightest talent to this organization.  This has a way of positively impacting culture which doesn’t feel contrived.  Plenty of resources are available for staff.  Benefits are very rich as are retirement options.
cons: Large organization that can move slow at times.

pros: I really feel like they care about their employees and really try to provide their employees with all the resources possible. My supervisor communicates very efficiently with me and makes sure we are always on the same page and that I am not over worked. They are very understanding and really try to make it an employee friendly environment.
cons: If you're working in research, funding can be tricky. But really though, nothing negative about working here.

job_title: Systems Analyst II in Houston, TX
pros: Good medical benefits and teachers retirement
cons: Terrible CEO and bad organizational politics based on who you know instead of what you know. No android support because they spend money on buildings, remodeling, parking garages in the medical center. Pay raises limited due to retirement pension and also hard to transfer and move up.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: When I first started they made sure that you were properly trained for the position.
cons: The department I worked in did not work with people with disabilities.  Then they hired new management that really did not know M. D. Anderson's way of doing things and they would take their inablities out on the employees.

job_title: Licensed & Certified Senior Pharmacy Technician in Houston, TX
pros:
After working at retail pharmacies, i can say straight without a doubt, that working at Mdanderson is the best place to work. 
Great benefits 
Great and safe work environment 
Nice colleagues
Feel  proud working at this institution
cons:
-Parking
-Shift not as flexible and the work every other weekend not my cup of tea personally. But can still enjoy my day off during the week, though i usually need two days consecutively for my body to rest.

review_title: satisfying with a very work friendly environment which is very conducive to learning new techniques
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros:
1) good work environment
2) good mentoring and very accomplished faculty
3) good growth in terms of learning curve
cons: Internship opportunities are not encouraged for PhD students who are not interested in academia. Also, overall the training provided is solely to train students to become postdocs or enter academia and not really for other career options

pros: There are only a few good reasons to work there. Because of its rich history and compensation /benefit package at over well the industry average.
cons: The stress of simply trying not to say, do or be the wrong thing on a daily basis presents a very unhealthy work environment. The overarching goal should be the best possible patient outcomes.

pros:
Patient ratios for RNs are optimal 2-3-4.
Opportunities to get involved in your practice (shared governance)
Tuition assistance for your MSN
Money for certifications, professional organizations, classes available. 
Overall excellent team work from all roles. 
Opportunities to transfer internally.
cons:
Hospital has current financial problems. Not sure if there will be layoffs. 
Similar to anywhere, its a demanding job and not everyone gives it their best. 
Large slow moving organization (bureaucratic).
Many excellent managers of nursing units. Some not so good.

pros: Surrounded by very intelectual people and endless opportunities to learn. Overall, very nice team to work with. Very fast pace environment.
cons: Poor management, lack of communication, poor business financial decisions that effect the hospital as a whole, and incompetent employees due to lack of training.

review_title: Great Benefits but culture could use some work
pros: Great benefits: paid healthcare, accrual of PTO, teacher's retirement funds. There are some great people that work there.
cons: Culture was one of retaliation, distrust, and everything moved very slowly. People who are low performers do not get reprimanded or dealt with and just hang around getting paid while doing minimal work.

pros: Benefits Package is great. Work environment from the lab, recruitment, HR and everyone else is friendly and very informative (makes the transition as easy as possible). Very big on making you feel like a part of the company and that your role plays a significant part in it.
cons: Hard to get past the application selection process, but once you are in its easy sailing

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: Great People and some departments are more efficient than others
cons: If you want to work in an environment where your have big brother and big sister and bigger brother and bigger sister looking over your shoulder - this is the place to be.

job_title: Senior Research Data Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: They have a great mentoring program, lots of opportunities for developing leadership skills, and the benefits are very good for an educational/non-profit organization.
cons: There is a lot of red-tape in getting things done partially because there are extra rules as part of state government/University of Texas, vertical career moves can be difficult unless you are willing to apply to positions in other departments (straight promotions are rare)

job_title: Research Assistant I in Houston, TX
pros: The staff are very kind. Very helpful environment. The cafeterias are filled with great food. Very motivating to work here.
cons: Did not feel safe reporting unprofessional situations when it involved my manager. The structure of my team was not what it was advertised. The pay was very low for my experience, education and for living in Houston.

pros: The atmosphere in the system is that of a team where everyone can work in a collaborative fashion without much, if any, struggle.

pros: Effective marketing and public relations departments.
cons:
Notice the trademark symbol every time MD Anderson mentions "making cancer history (R)?" This is because it wants to block other medical centers, academic institutions, and research universities from using this phrase. With an operating budget of four billion U.S. dollars, the MD Anderson health care enterprise is asserting that it alone will be "making cancer history (R)." From a legal prospective, no one else can claim to be "making cancer history (R)."

For now, let us put aside the obvious question of what would happen to MD Anderson if cancer were history, and let us examine the evidence of how committed MD Anderson is to cancer research.

1. In fiscal year 2017, MD Anderson allocated ~6% to research. (Operating budget reports are available on MD Anderson's website and these reports are discoverable by Google.)

2. MD Anderson still does not have a Chief Scientific Officer (an powerless ad interim officer is serving temporarily). A number of research departments are also without a Chair, because the former Chairs have moved on to greener pasture. There has been a mass exodus of faculty scientists from research departments and MD Anderson has only approved faculty searches for a small fraction of these vacant positions. The ranks of research scientists are dwindling at MD Anderson.

3. Faced with the mass exodus of scientists, instead of changing its environment and culture to better support research, MD Anderson resorts to alternative means to obstruct (well-funded) scientists from leaving, such as using spyware to monitor scientists' activities on the computers (Read the article on Keping Xie's in the Houston Chronicle published Feb 5, 2019.) For other scientists contemplating on moving to other U.S. research institutions, MD Anderson threatens to block these scientists from taking their grant money with them. Additionally, a number of foreign scientists are or have been under unfounded investigations for espionage. It is hard to imagine that scientists would do their best work under such a tangibly hostile environment.

4. On the ground, morale is low. Only an insignificant minority of MD Anderson scientists work after hours or on the weekends.

5. Wait. James Allison was awarded the 2018 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine (shared with Tasuku Honjo), and Dr. Allison is currently at MD Anderson, so this is sign that MD Anderson fosters a supportive research environment, right?

In reality, Dr. Allison's seminal work on CTLA4 published in 1996 was conducted at the University of California, Berkeley (1985 - 2004), and he continued this work at Memorial Sloan-Kettering (2006-2012) and Weil Cornell (2004-2012). The first translational success resulting in the Ipilimumab therapeutic was published in 2010 (N Engl J Med 2010; 363:711-723). Dr. Allison joined MD Anderson in 2012. This temporal sequence of events therefore fails to support the tenuous proposition that MD Anderson played a pivotal in fostering Dr. Allison's scientific success.

job_title: Inpatient Pharmacy Technician in Houston, TX
pros:
The pay is higher than average, but you are responsible for MUCH more than average.
I can't say anything bad about the benefit package. Health insurance is one of the best provided. Retirement package is also better than average.
cons:
Where to start. Management seems unable to manage employees or workflow at all. Every 3 months, employees are asked to incorporate new duties while still being responsible for old duties. Workflow is completely reorganized just as frequently, so no one, not even managers, is exactly sure who is supposed to be doing what. Co-workers for the most part are lazy or unqualified and management is unable to do anything about it. As long as an employee clocks in and out on time, Human Resources prevents management from disciplining that employee. This leads to many employees that show up on time, but do as little work as necessary. And the few employees that do work hard are fired because of occasional tardiness. 

Despite great pay and benefits, there is a high rotation for this position. Employees are constantly leaving and new employees are constantly being added to replace them. Training so many new employees puts a strain on current employees already saddled with ever increasing workloads. Also, pharmacy is responsible for the cleaning and storage of medical pumps, something that does not happen at any other hospital I know of. The pumps in question are usually dirty, bloody, and contaminated with infectious waste. Pharmacy is ill equipped to completely clean and sanitize these pumps, and they are stored in the same room as most of the medication.

pros: One of the handful of cancer hospitals exempt from CMS's prospective payment system for acute hospitalizations, so MD Anderson makes a lot of money (taxpayers everywhere should be outraged) -- and the institution's leaders are effective at shielding this cash from the rest of the public University of Texas system.  (Neither of these will last forever, however.)  Salaries, as a result, tend to be higher and/or less subject to downward budgetary pressures than elsewhere.  The workforce is incredibly diverse.
cons: The marketing department has built a advertising campaign around giving patients false hope that MD Anderson is somehow different, better, and capable of curing cancers that are not curable.  They justify this lack of integrity by stating that cancer patients have to go somewhere, so we might as well lure them here (i.e., the ends justify the means).  MD Anderson has grown rapidly and has been unable to attract, retain, and promote leaders who can effectively design operational processes that work well under higher patient volumns.  The operations are inefficient, byzantine, and frustrating for patients.  I would never seek medical care here.  The physicians on the front lines of patient care are engaged in a "ground war" with grossly overpaid and incompetent administrators, and with the institution's president, who is more interested in self-promotion than he is in building a world-class academic institution.  Finally, the HR department could not possibly be any worse.  They are literally walled off from the employee population in the administration building.  Getting hired can take several months longer than it should -- even up to a year, depending on the position!
